text: Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques   Threat Research Mahalo FIN7:
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and TechniquesNick Carr, Josh Yoder, Kimberly Goody, Scott Runnels, Jeremy Kennelly, Jordan Nuce Oct 10, 201911 min read |    Last updated:
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Mar 30, 2022 Threat ResearchMalwareDuring several recent incident response engagements, FireEye Mandiant investigators uncovered new tools in FIN7’s malware arsenal and kept pace as the global criminal operators attempted new evasion techniques.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: In this blog, we reveal two of FIN7’s new tools that we have called BOOSTWRITE and RDFSNIFFER.The first of FIN7's new tools is BOOSTWRITE – an in-memory-only dropper that decrypts embedded payloads using an encryption key retrieved from a remote server at runtime.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 has been observed making small changes to this malware family using multiple methods to avoid traditional antivirus detection, including a BOOSTWRITE sample where the dropper was signed by a valid Certificate Authority.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: One of the analyzed BOOSTWRITE variants contained two payloads: CARBANAK and RDFSNIFFER.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: While CARBANAK has been thoroughly analyzed and has been used maliciously by several financial attackers including FIN7, RDFSNIFFER is a newly-identified tool recovered by Mandiant investigators.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: RDFSNIFFER, a payload of BOOSTWRITE, appears to have been developed to tamper with NCR Corporation's “Aloha Command Center” client.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: NCR Aloha Command Center is a remote administration toolset designed to manage and troubleshoot systems within payment card processing sectors running the Command Center Agent.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The malware loads into the same process as the Command Center process by abusing the DLL load order of the legitimate Aloha utility.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant provided this information to NCR.BOOSTWRITE Loader: Where You At?BOOSTWRITE is a loader crafted to be launched via abuse of the DLL search order of applications which load the legitimate ‘Dwrite.dll’ provided by the Microsoft DirectX Typography Services.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The application loads the ‘gdi’ library, which loads the ‘gdiplus’ library, which ultimately loads ‘Dwrite’.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant identified instances where BOOSTWRITE was placed on the file system alongside the RDFClient binary to force the application to import DWriteCreateFactory from it rather than the legitimate DWrite.dll.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Once loaded, `DWrite.dll` connects to a hard-coded IP and port from which it retrieves a decryption key and initialization vector (IV) to decrypt two embedded payload DLLs.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: To accomplish this task, the malware first generates a random file name to be used as a text log under the current user's %TEMP% directory; this filename starts with ~rdf and is followed by a set of random numbers.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Next, the malware scans its own image to find the location of a 32-byte long multi-XOR key which is used to decode data inside its body.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Part of the decoded data is an IP address and port which are used to retrieve the key and the IV for the decryption of the embedded payloads.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The encryption algorithm uses the ChaCha stream cipher with a 256-bit key and 64-bit IV.Once the key and the IV are downloaded the malware decrypts the embedded payloads and performs sanity checks on the results.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The payloads are expected to be PE32.DLLs which, if the tests pass, are loaded into memory without touching the filesystem.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The malware logs various plaintext messages to the previously created logfile %TEMP%\~rds<rnd_numbers> which are indicative of the loader’s execution progress.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: An example of the file content is shown in Figure 1:Loading...Starting...Init OKKey OKData: 4606941HS: 20K:[32] V:[8]DCnt:
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: 732642317(ERR)Figure 1: BOOSTWRITE log fileBefore exiting, the malware resolves the location of the benign DWrite.dll library and passes the execution control to its DWriteCreateFactory method.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The malware decrypts and loads two payload DLLs.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: One of the DLLs is an instance of the CARBANAK backdoor; the other DLL is a tool tracked by FireEye as RDFSNIFFER which allows an attacker to hijack instances of the NCR Aloha Command Center Client application and interact with victim systems via existing legitimate 2FA sessions.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: RDFSNIFFER Module: We Smell a RATRDFSNIFFER is a module loaded by BOOSTWRITE which allows an attacker to monitor and tamper with legitimate connections made via NCR Corporation’s ‘Aloha Command Center Client’ (RDFClient), an application designed to provide visibility and system management capabilities to remote IT techs.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: RDFSNIFFER loads into the same process as the legitimate RDFClient by abusing the utility’s DLL load order, launching each time the ‘Aloha Command Center Client’ is executed on an impacted system.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: When the RDFSNIFFER module is loaded by BOOSTWRITE it hooks several Win32 API functions intended to enable it to tamper with NCR Aloha Command Center Client sessions or hijack elements of its user-interface (Table 1).
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Furthermore, this enables the malware to alter the user’s last input time to ensure application sessions do not time out.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Win32 API FunctionHook DescriptionCertVerifyCertificateChainPolicyUsed to man-in-the-middle SSL sessionsCertGetCertificateChainUsed to man-in-the-middle SSL sessionsWSAConnectUsed to man-in-the-middle socket connectionsconnectUsed to man-in-the-middle socket connectionsConnectExUsed to man-in-the-middle socket connectionsDispatchMessageWUsed to hijack the utility's UIDispatchMessageAUsed to hijack the utility's UIDefWindowProcWUsed to hijack the utility's UIDefWindowProcAUsed to hijack the utility's UIGetLastInputInfoUsed to change the user's last input time (to avoid timed lock outs)Table 1: RDFSNIFFER’s Hooked Win32 API FunctionsThis module also contains a backdoor component that enables it to inject commands into an active RDFClient session.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: This backdoor allows an attacker to upload, download, execute and/or delete arbitrary files (Table 2).Command NameLegit Function in RDFClientRDFClient Command IDDescriptionUploadFileMgrSendFile107Uploads a file to the remote systemDownloadFileMgrGetFile108Retrieves a file from the remote systemExecuteRunCommand3001Executes a command on the remote systemDeleteRemoteFileMgrDeleteFile3019Deletes file on remote systemDeleteLocal--Deletes a local fileTable 2: RDFSNIFFER’s Backdoor FunctionsSigned:
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Yours Truly, FIN7While the majority of BOOSTWRITE variants recovered from investigations have been unsigned, Mandiant identified a signed BOOSTWRITE sample used by FIN7 during a recent investigation.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Following that discovery, a signed BOOSTWRITE sample was uploaded to VirusTotal on October 3.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: This executable uses a code signing certificate issued by MANGO ENTERPRISE LIMITED (Table 3).MD5OrganizationCountrySeriala67d6e87283c34459b4660f19747a306mango ENTERPRISE LIMITEDGB32 7F 8F 10 74 78 42 4A BE B8 2A 85 DC 36 57 03 CC 82 70 5BTable 3: Code signing certificate used for BOOSTWRITEThis indicates the operators may be actively altering this malware to avoid traditional detection mechanisms.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, the signed BOOSTWRITE sample had a 0/68 detection ratio when it was uploaded to VirusTotal, demonstrating the effectiveness of this tactic (Figure 2).Figure 2: Current VirusTotal detection ratio for signed BOOSTWRITEUse of a code signing certificate for BOOSTWRITE is not a completely new technique for FIN7 as the group has used digital certificates in the past to sign their phishing documents, backdoors, and later stage tools.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: By exploiting the trust inherently provided by code certificates, FIN7 increases their chances of bypassing various security controls and successfully compromising victims.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The full evasion achieved against the detection engines deployed to VirusTotal – as compared to an unsigned BOOSTWRITE sample with an invalid checksum– illustrates that FIN7’s methods were effective in subverting both traditional detection and ML binary classification engines.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: This is a known issue and has been deeply studied since at least 2016’s “Chains of Distrust” research and 2017’s “Certified Malware” paper.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Since there are plenty of goodware samples with bad or no signatures – and a growing number of malware samples with good signatures – there is no easy solution here.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: The upside is that vendors selectively deploy engines to VirusTotal (including FireEye) and VT detection performance often isn’t a comprehensive representation of encountering full security technology stacks that implement detection-in-depth.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Later in this blog we further explore BOOSTWRITE’s PE Authenticode signature, its anomalies, and how code signing can be turned from a detection challenge into detection opportunities.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Outlook and ImplicationsWhile these incidents have also included FIN7’s typical and long-used toolsets, such as CARBANAK and BABYMETAL, the introduction of new tools and techniques provides further evidence FIN7 is continuing to evolve in response to security enhancements.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Further, the use of code signing in at least one case highlights the group's judicious use of resources, potentially limiting their use of these certificates to cases where they have been attempting to bypass particular security controls.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Barring any further law enforcement actions, we expect at least a portion of the actors who comprise the FIN7 criminal organization to continue conducting campaigns.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: As a result, organizations need to remain vigilant and continue to monitor for changes in methods employed by the FIN7 actors.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Sigs Up Dudes!
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Indicators, Toolmarks, and Detection OpportunitiesWhile FireEye does not release our production detection logic for the code families, this section does contain some identification and hunting concepts that we adopt in our layered detection strategy.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Table 4 contains malware samples referenced in this blog that FireEye is able to share from the larger set recovered during active investigations.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: TypeIndicator(s)BOOSTWRITE (signed)MD5: a67d6e87283c34459b4660f19747a306SHA-1: a873f3417d54220e978d0ca9ceb63cf13ec71f84SHA-256: 18cc54e2fbdad5a317b6aeb2e7db3973cc5ffb01bbf810869d79e9cb3bf02bd5C2: 109.230.199[.]227BOOSTWRITE (unsigned)MD5: af2f4142463f42548b8650a3adf5ceb2SHA1: 09f3c9ae382fbd29fb47ecdfeb3bb149d7e961a1SHA256: 8773aeb53d9034dc8de339651e61d8d6ae0a895c4c89b670d501db8dc60cd2d0C2:
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: 109.230.199[.]227Table 4: Publicly-shareable BOOSTWRITE samplesThe signed BOOSTWRITE sample has a PE Authenticode anomaly that can be detected using yara’s PE signature module.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Specifically, the PE linker timestamp is prior to the Authenticode validity period, as seen in Table 5.TimestampDescription2019-05-20 09:50:55 UTCSigned BOOSTWRITE’s PE compilation time2019-05-22 00:00 UTCthrough2020-05-21 23:59 UTCSigned BOOSTWRITE’s “mango ENTERPRISE LIMITED” certificate validity windowTable 5: Relevant executabe timestampsA public example of a Yara rule covering this particular PE Authenticode timestamp anomaly is available in a blog post from David Cannings, with the key logic shown in Figure 3.pe.number_of_signatures > 0 and not for all i in (0..pe.number_of_signatures - 1):     pe.signatures[i].valid_on(pe.timestamp)Figure 3: Excerpt of NCC Group’s research Yara ruleThere are other PE Authenticode anomalies that can also be represented as Yara rules to surface similarly suspicious files.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Of note, this signed BOOSTWRITE sample has no counter signature and, while the unauthenticated attributes timestamp structure is present, it is empty.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: In preparing this blog, FireEye’s Advanced Practices team identified a possible issue with VirusTotal’s parsing of signed executable timestamps as seen in Figure 4.Figure 4: Inconsistency in VirusTotal file signature timestamps for the signed BOOSTWRITE sampleFireEye filed a bug report with Google to address the discrepancy in VirusTotal in order to remove confusion for other users.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: To account for the detection weaknesses introduced by techniques like code signing, our Advanced Practices team combines the malicious confidence spectrum that comes from ML detection systems with file oddities and anomalies (weak signals) to surface highly interesting and evasive malware.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: This technique was recently described in our own Dr. Steven Miller’s Definitive Dossier of Devilish Debug Details.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: In fact, the exact same program database (PDB) path-based approach from his blog can be applied to the toolmarks seen in this sample for a quick hunting rule.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 5 provides the PDB path of the BOOSTWRITE samples from this blog.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: F:\projects\DWriteImpl\Release\DWriteImpl.pdbFigure 5: BOOSTWRITE PDB pathThe
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

text: It previously read "module_ls.dll", which is for Turla and unrelated.)Of course, resilient prevention capabilities are needed and to that end, FireEye detects this activity across our platforms.
source: Mahalo FIN7_ Responding to the Criminal Operators’ New Tools and Techniques _ Mandiant.html

FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign

Posted by
Michael Gorelik on November 21, 2018

Find me on:

LinkedIn
Twitter 



















Share











This blog was co-authored by Alon Groisman.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: It seems like the rumors of FIN7’s decline have been hasty.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text:
Just a few months after the well-publicized indictment of three high-ranking members in August, Morphisec has identified a new FIN7 campaign that appears to be targeting the restaurant industry.
FIN7, also known as Carbanak, is one of the major threat groups tracked by Morphisec and numerous other security entities, and among the top three criminal computer intrusion cases that the FBI is currently working.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: FIN7 is composed of a very sophisticated network of developers and hackers and brings in an estimated $50 million a month.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: They target very specific industries, hospitality – hotels and restaurants – being one of them, and are behind a string of high-profile breaches including Red Robin, Chili’s, Arby’s, Burgerville, Omni Hotels and Saks Fifth Avenue, among many others.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: FIN7 is known for its stealth techniques and ability to continuously evade security systems.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: In the case of Burgerville, malware sat on the company’s network collecting payment data for nearly a year before it was discovered.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: And that was only due to an FBI investigation.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: In this blog post, we present our findings on two campaigns, which occurred in the first and second weeks of November.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: These campaigns follow patterns similar to those presented by FireEye in August but with just enough variations to bypass many security vendors.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text:
Technical Description
The initial document was probably sent within the Baltic region (or tested there).
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: It was submitted to VirusTotal from Latvia.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: The name of the document translated from Russian is “new questioner”.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: It is password-protected with the password: “goodmorning”.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: Oprosnik_new.doc 6e1230088a34678726102353c622445e1f8b8b8c9ce1f025d11bfffd5017ca82)
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: It uses social engineering to convince the recipient to enable macros through the use of the images, logo and tagline of a newly launched, legitimate VPN tool InvinciBull by cybersecurity company Finjan.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: If the “enable macro” button is activated, the following obfuscated Macro runs and the next stage obfuscated JavaScript is extracted from the form caption, similar to the last several FIN7 campaigns.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: Examining the metadata of the document, it clearly shows that the document was created on the 11.02.2018:
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: Following deobfuscation of the macro, we notice known FIN7 patterns of executing JavaScript from VBScript with the slight modification of copying the wscript.exe file and renaming it to mses.exe.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: This may allow it to bypass some EDR solutions that are tracing WScript by name.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: Below is the obfuscated JavaScript that is written to the temp directory as error.txt file.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: The obfuscation pattern is similar to previously seen FIN7 patterns and most probably is a derivation of the same obfuscation toolkit.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text:
Deobfuscated JavaScript
The deobfuscated JavaScript is actually a backdoor component that directly communicates to the C2 server (in this case hxxps://bing-cdn[.]com).
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: It executes the response which is yet another JavaScript command, which can be evaluated by eval.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: Although there have been slight modifications in the Macro delivery in the last couple of campaigns, the JavaScript backdoor stays the same, including its communication protocol.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: During the first request, the MAC address and the computer domain are also delivered to the target C2.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: We believe that the next stage is only delivered to specific targets based on domains as the data that is delivered in the first request is very limited.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text:
Yara Rules
Some additional observations that can be used to create Yara-rules for this campaign are the locations of the loaded VBControl files that are written in clear text as part of the document files:

Additional Samples
After this search, we identified more samples that were created just a couple of days ago and point to a known C2 registered to the same entity (hxxps://googleapi-cdn[.]com)
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text:
Below is a summary of information for one of those documents:
The document was submitted from Ukraine (yet another former soviet union country) with the name “dinners.doc” (f5f8ab9863dc12d04731b1932fc3609742de68252c706952f31894fc21746bb8).
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: The document again uses the social engineering technique of spoofing a known and trusted entity to convince the victim to enable macros.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: Based on the submission date and creation time, the document is sent to the target within 2-3 days.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: The macro is nearly identical to that described above except that wscript->script, errors->settings, has multiple captions instead of a single one.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text:
The JavaScript backdoor is decrypted into a similar backdoor:

Conclusion
Like the Hydra, cutting off one, or even three, heads of FIN7 barely slows it down.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: With the holiday rush nearly upon us, we expect the threat group to step up its activities to take advantage of increased email traffic flow and seasonal staff that may be less security conscious.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text: Workers in any industry should stay vigilant against social engineering methods – although with today’s highly targeted campaigns this can sometimes be tough to spot.
source: FIN7 Not Finished – Morphisec Spots New Campaign.html

text:
And never enable macros unless you are 100 percent certain that the file is safe.

FIN7 Revisited: Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware
Despite the arrests of three prominent members of the FIN7 cybercrime gang beginning in January 2018, attacks targeting businesses and customer payment card information did not cease.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: SHARE
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
THIS:




























Flashpoint Intel Team 
March 20, 2019








 Table Of ContentsTable of ContentsNew Attack Panel and Malware SamplesSQLRat
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
Technical DetailsDNSbot Technical DetailsMitigationsAttachments and Downloads
By Joshua Platt and Jason Reaves
Despite the arrests of three prominent members of the FIN7 cybercrime gang beginning in January 2018, attacks targeting businesses and customer payment card information did not cease.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The latest evidence involves the discovery of a new administrative panel and previously unseen malware samples that Flashpoint analysts are linking to this notorious group.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Activity from this campaign dates from May to July 2018, but could go back farther to January 2018.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: FIN7 has been active since at least 2015, targeting more than 100 U.S.-based companies in 47 states, as well as businesses in Europe and Australia.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The U.S. companies affected were operating primarily in the hospitality, restaurant, and gaming industries, according to a U.S. Department of Justice press release last Aug. 1 announcing the arrest of three Ukrainian nationals alleged to be members of FIN7.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Two were arrested in January in Germany and Poland, while the third—an alleged supervisor—was arrested in June in Spain.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: FIN7, which has also used a backdoor linked to Carbanak—another prolific cybercrime outfit responsible for billions in losses in the financial services industry—has stolen more than 15 million payment card records from American businesses.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
The group, which operated behind a front company called Combi Security, has infiltrated more than 6,500 individual point-of-sale terminals at more than 3,600 business locations, according to the DoJ.
New Attack Panel and Malware Samples
Flashpoint analysts recently uncovered a new attack panel used by this group in campaigns they have called Astra.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The panel, written in PHP, functions as a script-management system, pushing attack scripts down to compromised computers.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Analysts discovered references to the FIN7 front company Combi Security in the Astra panel’s backend PHP code, connecting the group to these campaigns.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: According to the DoJ indictments, Combi Security purported itself as a penetration-testing and security services company based in Russia and Israel.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The DoJ alleges FIN7 portrayed Combi Security as a legitimate business in order to recruit other hackers to their operation.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The attackers gain an initial foothold on targeted machines via phishing emails containing malicious attachments.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The emails are often industry-specific and crafted to entice a victim to open the message and execute the attached document.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: One of the documents spreads what analysts are calling SQLRat, previously unseen malware that drops files and executes SQL scripts on the host system.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The use of SQL scripts is ingenious in that they don’t leave artifacts behind the way traditional malware does.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Once they are deleted by the attackers’ code, there is nothing left to be forensically recovered.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: This technique has not been observed in previous campaigns associated with FIN7.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The second new malware sample discovered is a multiprotocol backdoor called DNSbot, which is used to exchange commands and push data to and from compromised machines.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Primarily, it operates over DNS traffic, but can also switch to encrypted channels such as HTTPS or SSL, Flashpoint analysts discovered.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The campaigns maintain persistence on machines by creating two daily scheduled task entries.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The code, meanwhile, is still controlled by the FIN7 actors and may be leveraged in future attacks by the group.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
SQLRat Technical Details
SQLRat campaigns typically involved a lure document that included an image overlayed by a VB Form trigger.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The documents contained a message asking the user to “Unlock Protected Contents,” below, while showing a message box displaying “US SEC Unlock document service.”
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 1: An image of a document used in a typical campaign.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Once a user has double-clicked the embedded image, the form executes a VB setup script.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The script writes files to the path %appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\, then creates two task entries triggered to run daily.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 2: Executing scripts on disk.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The scripts are responsible for deobfuscating and executing the main JavaScript file mspromo.dot.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The file uses a character insertion obfuscation technique, making it appear to contain Chinese characters.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 3: Obfuscated mspromo file.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: After deobfuscating the file, the main JavaScript is easily recognizable.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: It contains a number of functions designed to drop files and execute scripts on a host system.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
Image 4: Deobfuscated mspromo script.=
The SQLRat script is designed to make a direct SQL connection to a Microsoft database controlled by the attackers and execute the contents of various tables.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The script retrieves an item from the bindata table and writes the file to disk.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: This file appears to primarily be a version of TinyMet—an open source Meterpreter stager—but the actors have the option to store and execute any binary loaded into the table.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 5: Code responsible for downloading from the database.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Files associated with the SQLRat campaigns were all SFX RAR files.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The files were 32/64-bit versions of a custom-built TinyMet along with a recon.js file.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The 32-bit file contained an XOR embedded .exe file.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The file was decoded out using the following:
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 6: Deobfuscate embedded “TiniMet,” a customized version of TinyMet.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The result is a customized version of TinyMet.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: This version has limited usage; it does reverse TCP, XOR decodes the data retrieved for execution of the stager, and looks for TrendMicro processes.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
This file calls itself TiniMet:
Image 7: TiniMet looking for TrendMicro processes.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
Analysts also uncovered a “TinyPS” stager:

After decoding out the blob, analysts found a PowerShell script.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: This script was similar to what was previously documented in the Trustwave report “Operation Grand Mars: Defending Against Carbanak Cyber Attacks.”
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The script contained the same XOR key but does not achieve persistence.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: It is only intended to create the Meterpreter session.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
The following is the PowerShell version of TiniMet:
Image 9: TinyPS PowerShell stager snippet.
DNSbot Technical Details
Analysts also uncovered subsequent campaigns associated with this panel.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: These campaigns were similar, but leveraged a document containing an embedded JavaScript-based DNSbot.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The document contained the same MsgBox display, but this time there was a single file and task.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The task name is similar to “Microsoft update service,” but the obfuscated JS file is dropped in %localappdata%\Storage:
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 10: DNSBot drop location.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Additionally, the same US SEC Unlock document service is displayed, though the Microsoft update service task is deleted and replaced with the DNSbot.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 11: DNSbot task update.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The JavaScript is heavily obfuscated.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The first variable—a—is an array of obfuscated values.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
The second line contains a function to deobfuscate the values, while the call to that function is the second variable, b:
Image 12: DNSbot obfuscation.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
A deobfuscated version of the DNS script is:
Image 13: DNSbot deobfuscated.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: A second deobfuscated testing script also matched components of the JavaScript embedded in the ASTRA docs, demonstrating the script’s multiprotocol use.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
The domain stats25-google[.]com was included in a report released by FireEye earlier in the year:
Image 14: Script relation to other reporting.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The ASTRA backend was installed on a Windows server with Microsoft SQL.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The panel was written in PHP and managed the content in the tables.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: It functioned as a script management system.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
Mitigations
Image 15: ASTRA attack panel partially redacted.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 16: FIN7 front company name.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Image 17: The file types that were inserted, along with a table layout of the database with partial redaction.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Flashpoint recommends watching for newly added Windows tasks, specifically those with a JScript switch.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: Also, monitor for attempts to delete the Microsoft update service.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
Flashpoint also recommends implementing host-based detections for new files in %appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\ with a dot extension, as well as implementing host-based detections for files in %appdata%\local\Storage\.
Attachments and Downloads
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text: The indicators of compromise (IOCs) for ASTRA panel, SQLRat, and DNSbot are available for download here.
source: FIN7 Revisited_ Inside Astra Panel and SQLRat Malware _ Flashpoint.html

text:
Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) 




Security / July 26, 2017

Footprints of FIN7: Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2)

 ATR   Justin Warner   Stephen Hinck  					





This is part two of a blog series detailing Gigamon Applied Threat Research’s (ATR) engagements with FIN7 throughout early 2017.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Part one focused the network communications and tradecraft involved with FIN7, specifically addressing how patterns in the C2 protocol allowed for Gigamon ATR to gain a deeper understanding of adversary TTPs.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In this post, we will break out one of the ways in which FIN7 profits from their victims — compromise of point-of-sale (POS) environments and theft of cardholder data.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
End Goal: Financial Gain
Based on victimology, internal attacker actions and known data exfiltration, many people have demonstrated FIN7’s clear financial motivations.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: With that said, up until recently, little detail has been shared about the tradecraft employed to accomplish that objective.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: During our engagements, Gigamon ATR observed a standalone utility that appeared to be custom in nature and used specifically to target POS systems.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Multi-Stage Dropper
During post-exploitation, FIN7 would gain access to the POS environment primarily using PSExec, combined with a custom PowerShell script to deploy their payload.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The weaponized PowerShell script was built to load an embedded DLL using reflective injection.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: While the PowerShell code appeared to include several foundational components from PowerSploit’s Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection, it also contained custom modifications that made it unique.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: To perform the exploit, the script executed code from PowerSploit designed to resolve Windows API functions necessary for performing the injection.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Next, the script would allocate memory in its current process and use the System.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Runtime.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Interopservices.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Marshal class to copy code into the newly allocated memory.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: With the DLL in memory, the script would then generate custom bootstrap code for binary loading and place that code into memory.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Finally, the script would create a thread at the offset of the bootstrap code that will in turn load the malicious payload from memory.
Figure 9: An example of the bootstrap generation code.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Once injected, the payload proceeded to write a binary encoded blob into the registry key
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\DRM and install persistence using a custom Shim targeting services.exe and adding it to the shim database by executing sdbinst.exe.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: When services.exe is executed on boot, the blob, which is primarily composed of a POS scraping capability, is loaded.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 10: Multistage loading process.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Based on previous public documentation of FIN7 operations, this custom PowerShell loader is a notable divergence from previous FIN7 operational tactics; a shift in techniques possibly to evade detection based on intel reporting.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Notably, there is an inherent risk of detection that an adversary must evaluate when deploying a persistence mechanism, especially in POS environments that experience relatively little day-to-day changes.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This shift identifies a likely desire to maintain longer-term access in order to facilitate ongoing theft from a single target environment over time, rather than performing smash and grab campaigns.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Scraper Payload
Once running, the POS scraping capability will attempt to inject itself into svchost.exe, wuauclt.exe or explorer.exe (in that order).
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Upon successful injection, the scraper enumerates running processes, comparing them to a list provided via a text file on disk.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This tactic of using a targeted set of processes allows the malware to be used flexibly in different environments and shows customization in targeting based on each individual victim.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Once the scraping capability has identified a process of interest, the payload will read memory from the process and extract track one and track two data formats.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Once extracted, the malware encrypts the data and writes it to disk for later collection by the threat actors.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Point-of-Sale Considerations
While working with customers of all different sizes and across industries, Gigamon ATR has seen a large mix of architectures that have had both successes and failures, largely as a result of decisions made during the design process.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: We work with our customers to understand how their individual environment design affects their ability to perform network monitoring, but by the time we are brought in to assist in response it’s too late and the priority is containment, mitigation and remediation with the topic of design being revisited in the wake of the breach.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: With that said, we hope to present some considerations that apply specifically to protecting and monitoring POS environments:
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Network isolation: POS systems and processing servers should be relatively isolated, with strict access controls applied in the environment.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In most POS environments, remote networks (such as those found in storefronts) have no need to connect directly to each other, instead network communication should exist only between the remote networks, and any centralized processing or storage resources.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Where possible, Gigamon ATR recommends the application of network controls that enforce this model.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Monitoring coverage:
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Wherever possible, Gigamon ATR recommends backhauling all internet traffic through centralized points of presence for ease of consistent monitoring.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: On multiple occasions, Gigamon ATR has witnessed the use of split tunneling (sending local traffic directly to the internet) create difficulties in monitoring that traffic.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This hinders or prevents the ability to detect malware communicating external to the environment.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Proxying and logging all network communications from POS systems, preferably in a robust security stack that allows for behavioral profiling, enables the detection of, and response to, threats in the environment.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Behavioral monitoring: Network traffic behavior in POS environments should be fairly predictable, and deviations from that behavior should warrant additional investigation.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By monitoring and baselining network flows within the POS environment, defenders can identify changes to those patterns.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Some examples of patterns to watch include: network traffic volume, hosts communicating with each other, the direction of that communication and the amount of data transmitted.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Application whitelisting: Similar to network behaviors, the applications running in POS environments remain fairly static.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Baselining the environment, and then applying controls that allow only a small set of required applications to execute on hosts involved in processing payment data, can prevent attackers from ever gaining a foothold on those systems.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Host-based firewalls:
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In addition to whitelisting applications allowed to execute on system involved in processing payment data, whitelisting the ports and IPs that each system is allowed to communicate on will help to prevent lateral movement within the POS environment.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Controlling network traffic, particularly on ports used for system management (commonly used for lateral movement), ensures that such activity can only occur from certain hosts, and can greatly increase (if not prevent completely, in combination with other controls) the amount of time it takes to pivot within the POS environment, increasing the likelihood of discovery of an active attacker.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Conclusion
The information-security industry as a whole commonly puts a lot of focus on top tier threats such as nation-state actors.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: While very real, these threats are a part of a different model than most organizations should likely consider.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: There are serious threats facing the average business and these groups continue to elevate their sophistication and learn from their engagements.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: With one goal in mind, these actors will continue to attack environments in an effort to profit off of the blindness of their victims.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: While FIN7 is a moderately sophisticated threat, the patterns of their operations and tradecraft decisions can be reliably detected by anyone with good visibility into their environment.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Further, early investments in security-focused design and realistic threat modeling will allow organizations to better prepare for the inevitable targeting by one of these groups.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: We hope that these posts were insightful and allow you to bring similar defensive tradecraft into your environment.
source: Footprints of FIN7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 2) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection 




Security / October 8, 2017

Footprints of Fin7:
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection

 ATR  					





The Gigamon Applied Threat Research (ATR) team actively tracks threat activity associated with FIN7, a financially motivated actor targeting the retail industry.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: FIN7 has been constantly adapting their phishing documents in order to evade detection — their latest update has initial detections on VirusTotal of 0/59 and 1/59 for the RTF and DOCX formats, respectively.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: FIN7 leverages a number of targeted phishing techniques to initially exploit victims in the retail sector.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Once they have an initial foothold the actor pivots to Point of Sale systems and steals large quantities of protected card data.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In August, the Gigamon ATR team released a large set of indicators of compromise (IOCs) for infected document payloads that displayed similar infection characteristics and techniques to each other.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Recently, the Gigamon ATR team observed a shift in techniques including a modified payload that uses a new embedded file type.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Additionally, FIN7 has modified the obfuscation utilized by their HALFBAKED backdoor — likely to avoid detection in new or ongoing campaigns.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: While the newly observed malicious documents do not represent a “new” attack methodology, the change of payload may cause detection issues for legacy signatures and heuristic detections which utilize overly strict detection mechanisms, lacking in durability or layered coverage.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This post details the newly observed methods and provides indicators associated with the identified infection documents.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This will enable retail companies to validate their detections and leverage this intelligence to determine if they’ve been impacted by new campaigns.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Shifting Techniques
Initial Payload
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In past versions of infection documents, the Gigamon ATR team observed the actor primarily utilize malicious shortcut files (LNK) or visual basic scripts (VBS or VBE) to achieve code execution from within their lure.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: These malicious files are embedded into the infection documents using the Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) framework within Windows, which allows objects from one application to be included in another.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In the documents released today, FIN7 appears to have pivoted from using OLE embedded LNK files to using OLE embedded CMD files.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: When executed, the CMD file writes JScript to “tt.txt” under the current user’s home directory.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The batch script then copies itself to “pp.txt”, also under the current user’s home directory, before running WScript using the JScript engine on the file.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This JScript code will read from the file “pp.txt”, skipping the first four lines (the CMD code itself), but otherwise evaluating anything after the first character for each line in the file.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Although different in implementation, this is a familiar technique, as FIN7 frequently runs commented out code that they read as a string through the use of JScript’s “eval” function.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Both CMD and LNK file formats result in code execution, but the shift towards using CMD files may indicate a desire to stay ahead of detection authors.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Halfbaked Obfuscation Change
Over the course of the past year, the actor’s unique backdoor, HALFBAKED, has continued to morph to improve capabilities and reduce detection surface.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In the newest observed version, the Gigamon ATR team observed a slight tweak in the obfuscation strategy.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Previously, different stages of the HALFBAKED codebase utilized base64 encoding, stored in a string array variable called “srcTxt”.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
The attacker now obfuscates that name and continues to break up the base64 string into multiple strings within an array as seen in Figure 1.
Figure 1: Base64 encoded chunk of the new HALFBAKED functionality.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
New Halfbaked Feature
Additionally, the HALFBAKED backdoor now includes a built-in command called “getNK2”, seen here in HALFBAKED’s command list (Figure 2).
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: “getNK2” is designed to retrieve the victim’s Microsoft Outlook email client auto-complete list.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This may suggest the actor’s desire to obtain new phishing targets within a victim organization.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: If any of these new targets fell victim to the phishing lure, it would allow FIN7 to increase their foothold within a victim organization’s network and potentially pivot to new areas.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 2: HALFBAKED commands including the recent getNK2 addition.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The command “getNK2” is likely named after outlook’s NK2 file, which contains a list of auto-complete addresses for Microsoft Outlook 2007 and 2010.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Newer versions of outlook no longer use the NK2 file, so FIN7 has also written functionality to handle newer versions of Outlook within the same “getNK2” command.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
The command will execute the JScript function in Figure 3 on the victim system.
Figure 3: getNK2 command functionality.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Conclusion
Detection authors must make trade-offs to optimize signature performance; narrow signatures lead to high fidelity detections, but risk missing changes in actor behaviors, meanwhile broader detection patterns provide better coverage, at the risk of more false positives.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Combatting a well-resourced and adaptive adversary requires a layered approach of both signature styles.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: FIN7 has demonstrated that they are highly adaptable, evading detection mechanisms while impacting a number of large US retail companies over an extended period of time.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The Gigamon ATR team will continue to remain vigilant, working to understand FIN7 and empower our customers and affected industries to defend themselves.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This article was written by ATR team members Alex Sirr and Spencer Walden.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Gigamon ThreatINSIGHT™ is a network security analytics solution that offers a SaaS capability that enables customers to gain and utilize widespread network visibility for security operations.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: As part of its research, the Gigamon ATR team coordinates disclosure of security threats and vulnerabilities with relevant parties in order to maximize both the response and victim remediation efforts as well as working to truly improve the security of customers and other victims prior to publishing blog posts.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: To learn more about the Gigamon ATR team, please visit www.gigamon.com/research/applied-threat-research-team.html.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Pushing New Techniques to Evade Detection - Gigamon Blog.html

text: FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence   Threat Research To SDB, Or Not To SDB:
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for PersistenceMatthew McWhirt, Jon Erickson, DJ Palombo May 03, 20174 min read |    Last updated: Nov 04, 2021 In 2017, Mandiant responded to multiple incidents we attribute to FIN7, a financially motivated threat group associated with malicious operations dating back to 2015.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Throughout the various environments, FIN7 leveraged the CARBANAK backdoor, which this group has used in previous operations.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: A unique aspect of the incidents was how the group installed the CARBANAK backdoor for persistent access.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant identified that the group leveraged an application shim database to achieve persistence on systems in multiple environments.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: The shim injected a malicious in-memory patch into the Services Control Manager (“services.exe”) process, and then spawned a CARBANAK backdoor process.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant identified that FIN7 also used this technique to install a payment card harvesting utility for persistent access.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: This was a departure from FIN7’s previous approach of installing a malicious Windows service for process injection and persistent access.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Application Compatibility Shims BackgroundAccording to Microsoft, an application compatibility shim is a small library that transparently intercepts an API (via hooking), changes the parameters passed, handles the operation itself, or redirects the operation elsewhere, such as additional code stored on a system.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Today, shims are mainly used for compatibility purposes for legacy applications.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: While shims serve a legitimate purpose, they can also be used in a malicious manner.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant consultants previously discussed shim databases at both BruCon and BlackHat.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Shim Database RegistrationThere are multiple ways to register a shim database on a system.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: One technique is to use the built-in “sdbinst.exe” command line tool.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 1 displays the two registry keys created when a shim is registered with the “sdbinst.exe” utility.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 1: Shim database registry keysOnce
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: a shim database has been registered on a system, the shim database file (“.sdb” file extension) will be copied to the “C:\Windows\AppPatch\Custom” directory for 32-bit shims or “C:\Windows\AppPatch\Custom\Custom64” directory for 64-bit shims.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Malicious Shim Database InstallationTo install and register the malicious shim database on a system, FIN7 used a custom Base64 encoded PowerShell script, which ran the “sdbinst.exe” utility to register a custom shim database file containing a patch onto a system.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 2 provides a decoded excerpt from a recovered FIN7 PowerShell script showing the parameters for this command.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 2: Excerpt from a FIN7 PowerShell script to install a custom shimFIN7 used various naming conventions for the shim database files that were installed and registered on systems with the “sdbinst.exe” utility.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: A common observance was the creation of a shim database file with a “.tmp” file extension (Figure 3).Figure 3: Malicious shim database exampleUpon registering the custom shim database on a system, a file named with a random GUID and an “.sdb” extension was written to the 64-bit shim database default directory, as shown in Figure 4.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: The registered shim database file had the same MD5 hash as the file that was initially created in the “C:\Windows\Temp” directory.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 4: Shim database after registrationIn addition, specific registry keys were created that correlated to the shim database registration.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 5 shows the keys and values related to this shim installation.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 5: Shim database registry
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: keysThe database description used for the shim database registration, “Microsoft KB2832077” was interesting because this KB number was not a published Microsoft Knowledge Base patch.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: This description (shown in Figure 6) appeared in the listing of installed programs within the Windows Control Panel on the compromised system.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 6: Shim database as an installed applicationMalicious Shim Database DetailsDuring the investigations, Mandiant observed that FIN7 used a custom shim database to patch both the 32-bit and 64-bit versions of “services.exe” with their CARBANAK payload.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: This occurred when the “services.exe” process executed at startup.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: The shim database file contained shellcode for a first stage loader that obtained an additional shellcode payload stored in a registry key.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: The second stage shellcode launched the CARBANAK DLL (stored in a registry key), which spawned an instance of Service Host (“svchost.exe”) and injected itself into that process.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 7 shows a parsed shim database file that was leveraged by FIN7.Figure 7: Parsed shim database fileFor the first stage loader, the patch overwrote the “ScRegisterTCPEndpoint” function at relative virtual address (RVA) “0x0001407c” within the services.exe process with the malicious shellcode from the shim database file.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: The new “ScRegisterTCPEndpoint” function (shellcode) contained a reference to the path of “\REGISTRY\MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\DRM”, which is a registry location where additional malicious shellcode and the CARBANAK DLL payload was stored on the system.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 8 provides an excerpt of the parsed patch structure within the recovered shim database file.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 8: Parsed patch structure from the shim database fileThe shellcode stored within the registry path “HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\DRM” used the API function “RtlDecompressBuffer” to decompress the payload.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: It then slept for four minutes before calling the CARBANAK DLL payload's entry point on the system.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Once loaded in memory, it created a new process named “svchost.exe” that contained the CARBANAK DLL.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Bringing it TogetherFigure 9 provides a high-level overview of a shim database being leveraged as a persistent mechanism for utilizing an in-memory patch, injecting shellcode into the 64-bit version of “services.exe”.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 9: Shim database code injection processDetectionMandiant recommends the following to detect malicious application shimming in an environment:Monitor for new shim database files created in the default shim database directories of “C:\Windows\AppPatch\Custom” and “C:\Windows\AppPatch\Custom\Custom64”Monitor for registry key creation and/or modification events for the keys of “HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\AppCompatFlags\Custom” and “HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\AppCompatFlags\InstalledSDB”Monitor process execution events and command line arguments for malicious use of the “sdbinst.exe” utility  Link to RSS feedPrepare for 2024's cybersecurity landscape.
source: To SDB, Or Not To SDB_ FIN7 Leveraging Shim Databases for Persistence _ Mandiant.html
