text:
APT reports

08 May 2019

 10 minute read								








 

Authors



 Yury Namestnikov




Félix Aime
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: On August 1, 2018, the US Department of Justice announced that it had arrested several individuals suspected of having ties to the FIN7 cybercrime rig.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: FIN7 operations are linked to numerous intrusion attempts having targeted hundreds of companies since at least as early as 2015.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Interestingly, this threat actor created fake companies in order to hire remote pentesters, developers and interpreters to participate in their malicious business.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The main goal behind its malicious activities was to steal financial assets from companies, such as debit cards, or get access to financial data or computers of finance department employees in order to conduct wire transfers to offshore accounts.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: In 2018-2019, researchers of Kaspersky Lab’s Global Research and Analysis Team analyzed various campaigns that used the same Tactics Tools and Procedures (TTPs) as the historic FIN7, leading the researchers to believe that this threat actor had remained active despite the 2018 arrests.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: In addition, during the investigation, we discovered certain similarities to other attacker groups that seemed to share or copy the FIN7 TTPs in their own operations.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Recent FIN7 campaigns
The FIN7 intrusion set continued its tailored spear phishing campaigns throughout last year.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Kaspersky Lab has been able to retrieve some of these exchanges from a FIN7 target.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The spear phishing campaigns were remarkably sophisticated from a social engineering perspective.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: In various cases, the operators exchanged numerous messages with their victims for weeks before sending their malicious documents.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The emails were efficient social-engineering attempts that appealed to a vast number of human emotions (fear, stress, anger, etc.) to elicit a response from their victims.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: One of the domains used by the attackers in their 2018 campaign of spear phishing contained more than 130 email aliases, leading us to think that more than 130 companies had been targeted by the end of 2018.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Malicious Documents
We have seen two types of documents sent to victims in these spear phishing campaigns.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The first one exploits the INCLUDEPICTURE feature of Microsoft Word to get context information about the victim’s computer, and the availability and version number of Microsoft Word.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The second one, which in many cases is an Office document protected with a trivial password, such as “12345”, “1234”, etc., uses macros to execute a GRIFFON implant on the target’s computer.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: In various cases, the associated macro also scheduled tasks to make GRIFFON persistent.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Interestingly, following some open-source publications about them, the FIN7 operators seems to have developed a homemade builder of malicious Office document using ideas from ThreadKit, which they employed during the summer of 2018.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The new builder inserts random values in the Author and Company metadata fields.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Moreover, the builder allows these to modify different IOCs, such as the filenames of wscript.exe or sctasks.exe copies, etc.

IOCs extracted from regular documents associated to GRIFFON
GRIFFON Implant
Griffon Malware attack pattern
The GRIFFON implant is a lightweight JScript validator-style implant without any persistence mechanism.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The malware is designed for receiving modules to be executed in-memory and sending the results to C2s.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We were able to obtain four different modules during the investigation.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Reconnaissance module
The first module downloaded by the GRIFFON malware to the victim’s computer is an information-gathering JScript, which allows the cybercriminals to understand the context of the infected workstation.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: This module mainly relies on WMI and Windows objects to deliver results, which will be sent back to the operators.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Interestingly, more than 20 artifacts are retrieved from the system by this implant during the reconnaissance stage, from the date and time of operating system installation and membership in a Windows domain to a list of and the resolutions of the workstation’s monitors.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Meterpreter downloader
The second module is used by the operators to execute an obfuscated PowerShell script, which contains a Meterpreter downloader widely known as “Tinymet“.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: This downloader, seen in past FIN7 campaigns, downloads a one-byte XOR-encrypted (eg.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: with the key equal to 0x50 or 0x51) piece of meterpreter shellcode to execute.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Screenshot module
The third module allows the operators to take a screenshot of the remote system.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: To do that, it also drops a PowerShell script on the workstation to execute.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The script executes an open-source .NET class used for taking a screenshot.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The resulting screenshot is saved at “%TMP%/image.png”, sent back to the attackers by the GRIFFON implant and then deleted.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Persistence module
The last retrieved module is a persistence module.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: If the victim appears valuable to the attackers, a GRIFFON implant installer is pushed to the victim’s workstation.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: This module stores another instance of the GRIFFON implant inside the registry to achieve persistence.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Here is a PowerLinks-style method used by the attackers to achieve persistence and execute the GRIFFON implant at each user logon.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The new GRIFFON implant is written to the hard drive before each execution, limiting the “file-less” aspect of this method.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Through its light weight and modular architecture, the GRIFFON implant is the perfect validator.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Even though we have been able to retrieve four different modules, it is possible that the FIN7 operators have more modules in their toolsets for achieving their objectives on the victim’s workstation.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
On the hunt for GRIFFON infrastructure
Attackers make mistakes, and FIN7 are no exception.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The major error made by its operators allowed us to follow the command and control server of the GRIFFON implant last year.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: In order to trick blue teams and other DFIR analysts, the operators created fake HTTP 302 redirection to various Google services on their C2s servers.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Server: nginx
Date: [retracted]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Content-Length: 0
Connection: keep-alive
Location: https://cloud.google.com/cdn/




1234567

HTTP/1.1 302 FoundServer: nginxDate: [retracted]Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8Content-Length: 0Connection: keep-aliveLocation: https://cloud.google.com/cdn/




Returned headers for most of the GRIFFON C2s servers on port 443
This error allowed us to follow the infrastructure week by week, until an individual pushed on Twitter the heuristic to track their C2 at the end of December 2018.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: A few days after the tweet, in January 2019, the operators changed their landing page in order to prevent this type of tracking against their infrastructure.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Fake pentest company
During the investigation related to the GRIFFON infrastructure, we found a strange overlap between the WHOIS record of an old GRIFFON C2 and the website of a fake company.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: According to the website, that domain supposedly belongs to a legitimate security company “fully owned by the Russian Government” (sic.)
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: and having offices in “Moscow, Saint Petersburg and Yekaterinburg”, but the address says the company is located in Trump Tower, in New York.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Given FIN7’s previous use of false security companies, we decided to look deeper into this one.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: As we were looking at the content of the website, it became evident that almost all of the text used was lifted from legitimate security-company websites.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Phrases and sentences were borrowed from at least the following companies/sites:

DKSec – www.dksec.com
OKIOK – www.okiok.com/services/tailored-solutions
MainNerve – www.mainnerve.com
Datics – www.datatics.com/cyber-security
Perspective Risk – www.perspectiverisk.com
Synack – https://www.synack.com/company
FireEye – https://www.fireeye.com/services/penetration-testing.html

This company seems to have been used by the FIN7 threat actor to hire new people as translators, developers and pentesters.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: During our research, we found various job advertisements associated with the company on freelance and remote-work websites.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: In addition to that, various individuals have mentioned the company in their resumes.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We believe that some of these individuals may not even be aware that they are working for a cybercrime business.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Links to other intrusion sets
While tracking numerous threat actors on a daily basis during the final days of 2018 and at the beginning of 2019, we discovered various activity clusters sharing certain TTPs associated with the FIN7 intrusion set.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
The link between these threat actors and FIN7 is still weak, but we decided to disclose a few hints regarding these in this blog post.
CobaltGoblin/EmpireMonkey
In his history, FIN7 has overlapped several times with Cobalt/EmpireMonkey in terms of TTPs.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: This activity cluster, which Kaspersky Lab has followed for a few years, uses various implants for targeting mainly banks, and developers of banking and money processing software solutions.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: At the end of 2018, the cluster started to use not only CobaltStrike but also Powershell Empire in order to gain a foothold on the victims’ networks.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: After a successful penetration, it uses its own backdoors and the CobaltStrike framework or Powershell Empire components to hop to interesting parts of the network, where it can monetize its access.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: FIN7’s last campaigns were targeting banks in Europe and Central America.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: This threat actor stole suspected of stealing €13 million from Bank of Valetta, Malta earlier this year.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Example of malicious documents used in the end of 2018 to beginning of 2019
A few interesting overlaps in recent FIN7 campaigns:

Both used macros to copy wscript.exe to another file, which began with “ms” (mses.exe – FIN7, msutil.exe – EmpireMonkey).
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Both executed a JScript file named “error” in %TEMP% (Errors.txt in the case of FIN7, Errors.bat for EmpireMonkey).
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Both used DocuSign decoy documents with different macros.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The macros popped the same “Document decryption error” error message—even if macro code remain totally different.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We have a high level of confidence in a historic association between FIN7 and Cobalt, even though we believe that these two clusters of activity are operated by different teams.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
AveMaria
AveMaria is a new botnet, whose first version we found in September 2018, right after the arrests of the FIN7 members.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We have medium confidence that this botnet falls under the FIN7 umbrella.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: In fact, AveMaria is a classic infostealer bot that collects all possible credentials from various types of software: browsers, email clients, messengers, etc., and can act as a keylogger.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Since the beginning of 2019, we have collected more than 1300 samples and extracted more than 130 C2s.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: To deliver their malware, the cyber criminals use spearphishing emails with various types of attachments: MS Office documents or spreadsheet files exploiting some known vulnerability like CVE-2017-11882, or documents with Ole2Link and SCT.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: They also use AutoIT droppers, password-protected EXE files and even ISO images.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: What is interesting, in some emails, they ask targets to phone them if they have any questions, like the FIN7 guys do.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Example of AveMaria spearphing emails.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Criminals suggest calling them.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: During the investigation into FIN7, our threat-hunting systems found an interesting overlap in between the infrastructure of FIN7 and AveMaria.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Basically, two servers in the same IP range and AS14576 (autonomous system) share a non-standard SSH port, which is 222.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: One of the servers is a Griffon C2, and the other one, an AveMaria C2.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Distribution of targets is another factor suggesting that these two malware families may be connected.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We analyzed AveMaria targets during February and March of 2019.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The spearphishing emails were sent to various kinds of businesses only and did not target individuals.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Thirty percent of the targets were small and medium-sized companies that were suppliers or service providers for bigger players and 21% were various types of manufacturing companies.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We also spotted several typical FIN7 targets, such as retailers and hotels.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Most AveMaria targets (72%) were in the EU.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
CopyPaste
At the end of 2018, while searching for new FIN7 campaigns via telemetry, we discovered a set of activity that we temporarily called “CopyPaste” from a previously unknown APT.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Interestingly, this actor targeted financial entities and companies in one African country, which lead us to think that CopyPaste was associated with cybermercenaries or a training center.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: This set of activity relied on open-source tools, such as Powershell Empire, and well-documented red teaming techniques, in order to get a foothold within the victim’s networks and avoid detection.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Here are the main similarities between CopyPaste and FIN7:

Both used the same Microsoft PowerShell argument obfuscation order: “powershell.exe -NoP
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: -NonI -ExecutionPolicy
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Bypass”.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We have only seen FIN7 and CopyPaste use this argument list for executing their malicious Powershell Scripts.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Both used decoy 302 HTTP redirections and typosquatting on their C2s (reminiscent of Cobalt and FIN7).
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The Empire C2s associated with CopyPaste had decoy redirections to Digitcert and Microsoft websites and used decoy job employment and tax websites with decoy redirections to host their payloads.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: FIN7 and Cobalt used decoy 302 HTTP redirections too, FIN7 on its GRIFFON C2s before January 2018, and Cobalt, on its staging servers, similar to CopyPaste.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Quite recently, FIN7 threat actors typosquatted the brand “Digicert” using the domain name digicert-cdn[.]com, which is used as a command and control server for their GRIFFON implants.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: CopyPaste, in turn, also typosquatted this brand with their domains digicertweb[.]com and digi-cert[.]org, both used as a Powershell Empire C2 with decoy HTTP 302 redirects to the legitimate Digicert website.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The links between CopyPaste and FIN7 are still very weak.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: It is possible that the CopyPaste operators were influenced by open-source publications and do not have any ties with FIN7.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text:
Conclusions
During 2018, Europol and DoJ announced the arrest of the leader of the FIN7 and Carbanak/CobaltGoblin cybercrime groups.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: It was believed that the arrest of the group leader will have an impact on the group’s operations.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: However, recent data seems to indicate that the attacks have continued without significant drawbacks.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: One may say CobaltGoblin and FIN7 have even extended the number of groups operating under their umbrella.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We observe, with various level of confidence, that there are several interconnected groups using very similar toolkits and the same infrastructure to conduct their cyberattacks.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The first of them is the well-known FIN7, which specializes in attacking various companies to get access to financial data or PoS infrastructure.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: They rely on a Griffon JS backdoor and Cobalt/Meterpreter, and in recent attacks, Powershell Empire.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The second one is CobaltGoblin/Carbanak/EmpireMonkey, which uses the same toolkit, techniques and similar infrastructure but targets only financial institutions and associated software/services providers.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: We link the AveMaria botnet to these two groups with medium confidence: AveMaria’s targets are mostly suppliers for big companies, and the way AveMaria manages its infrastructure is very similar to FIN7.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The last piece is the newly discovered CopyPaste group, who targeted financial entities and companies in one African country, which lead us to think that CopyPaste was associated with cybermercenaries or a training center.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: The links between CopyPaste and FIN7 are still very weak.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: It is possible that the operators of this cluster of activity were influenced by open-source publications and do not have any ties with FIN7.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: All of the aforementioned groups greatly benefit from unpatched systems in corporate environments.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: They thus continue to use effective spearphishing campaigns in conjunction with well-known MS Office exploits generated by the framework.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: So far, the groups have not used any zero-days.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: FIN7/Cobalt phishing documents may seem basic, but when combined with their extensive social engineering and focused targeting, they are quite successful.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: As with their previous fake company “Combi Security”, we are confident that they continue to create new personas for use in either targeting or recruiting under a “new” brand, “IPC”.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: More information about these and related attacks is available to customers of Kaspersky Intelligence Reports.
source: FIN7.5_ the infamous cybercrime rig “FIN7” continues its activities _ Securelist.html

text: Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation   Threat Research On the Hunt for FIN7:
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal OperationNick Carr, Kimberly Goody, Steve Miller, Barry Vengerik Aug 01, 201825 min read |    Last updated: Nov 08, 2021 Threat ResearchOn Aug. 1, 2018, the United States District Attorney’s Office for the Western District of Washington unsealed indictments and announced the arrests of three individuals within the leadership ranks of a criminal organization that aligns with activity we have tracked since 2015 as FIN7.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: These malicious actors are members of one of the most prolific financial threat groups of this decade, having carefully crafted attacks targeted at more than 100 organizations.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 is referred to by many vendors as “Carbanak Group,” although we do not equate all usage of the CARBANAK backdoor with FIN7.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: This blog explores the range of FIN7's criminal ventures, the technical innovation and social engineering ingenuity that powered their success, a glimpse into their recent campaigns, their apparent use of a security company as a front for criminal operations, and what their success means for the threat landscape moving forward.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: With this release, FireEye is also providing technical context, historical indicators, and techniques that organizations can use to hunt for FIN7 behavior enterprise-wide.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 Does the Crime...
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: The threat group is characterized by their persistent targeting and large-scale theft of payment card data from victim systems, which it has monetized at least a portion of through a prominent card shop.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: But FIN7’s financial operations were not limited to card data theft.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: In some instances, when they encountered and could not obtain payment card data from point of sale (POS) systems secured with end-to-end encryption (E2EE) or point-to-point encryption (P2PE), FIN7 pivoted to target finance departments within their victim organizations.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Furthermore, in April 2017, FireEye reported that FIN7 sent spear phishing emails to personnel involved with United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings at multiple organizations, providing further insight into FIN7’s targeting.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: These targeted individuals would likely have access to material non-public information that FIN7 actors could use to gain a competitive advantage in stock trading.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Diversification of their monetization tactics has allowed the group to impact a wide range of industries beyond those solely associated with payment card industry.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: During campaigns that FireEye associates with FIN7, victims within the following sectors have been targeted within the United States and Europe:Restaurants                                                                *Travel                                                               Hospitality                                                                   *EducationCasinos and Gaming                                                  *ConstructionEnergy                                                                        *RetailFinance                                                                       *TelecommunicationsHigh-tech                                                                    *GovernmentSoftware                                                                     *Business servicesFIN7’s Innovation Enabled their SuccessThroughout FireEye’s tracking of FIN7 campaigns, the attackers have attempted to stay ahead of the game and thwart detection, using novel tactics and displaying characteristics of a well-resourced operation.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: For example, in April 2017, FireEye blogged about FIN7’s spear phishing emails that leveraged hidden shortcut files (LNK files) to initiate the infection and VBScript functionality launched by mshta.exe to infect the victim.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: This was a direct departure from their established use of weaponized Office macros and highlighted the group’s adaptive nature to evade detection.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye also previously reported on FIN7’s use of the CARBANAK backdoor as a post-exploitation tool to cement their foothold in a network and maintain access to victim environments.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: CARBANAK is well known for its use in highly profitable and sophisticated attacks dating back to 2013, with usage attributable to FIN7 beginning in late 2015, although how interconnected the campaigns employing the malware over this five-year span are is unclear.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7’s use of CARBANAK is particularly notable due to their use of creative persistence mechanisms to launch the backdoor.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: The group leveraged an application shim database that injected a malicious in-memory patch into the Services Control Manager ("services.exe") process, and then spawned a CARBANAK backdoor process.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 also used this tactic to install a payment card harvesting utility.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Another notable characteristic of FIN7 has been their heavy use of digital certificates.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Unsurprisingly, malicious threat actors have sought to exploit the legitimacy afforded by these certificates.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: By digitally signing their phishing documents, backdoors and later stage tools, FIN7 was able to bypass many security controls that may limit execution of macros from Office documents and restrict execution of unsigned binaries on trusted systems.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: OrganizationCountrySerialEmailKorsar
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Travel TOVUA88:21:ac:7e:6c:da:11:00:1d:b3:d3:1a:16:c1:5c:26korsartravel@bk.ruKaitschuck
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: JamesGB30:2e:7f:14:3a:f3:f3:98:20:70:42:4e:ea:52:5d:d2oliversoftware@hotmail.comPark TravelRU4d:e2:87:56:98:bf:c7:74:a3:f3:47:d6:70:7c:9b:f0inga@parktravel-mx.ruTable 1: Sample FIN7 code signing certificatesFIN7 developed evasive techniques at a rapid pace.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Throughout 2017, FIN7 was observed creating novel obfuscation methods, and in some cases modifying the methods on a daily basis while launching attacks targeting multiple victims.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: The threat group regularly tested malicious DOC, DOCX, and RTF phishing documents against public repositories to check static detection engine coverage.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Their development of a payload obfuscation style using the Windows command interpreter's (cmd.exe) native string substitution was so unique that FireEye dubbed it "FINcoding."
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: These methods inspired deep command line obfuscation research and the release of Daniel Bohannon's Invoke-DOSfuscation.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Reference Table 2 and Table 3 for a selection of samples and their associated command line obfuscation techniques.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7’s Relentless Phone Calls and BellyachingOver the three years of responding to a multitude of compromises and proactively defending against FIN7, FireEye observed unprecedented social engineering prowess.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: From leveraging web forms for initial contact to targeting and engaging directly with pre-determined store managers, the operators demonstrated a range of capabilities.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7’s reach extended beyond their targets’ computer systems.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye has responded to incidents where FIN7 has called victims prior to lodging digital complaints laden with malicious documents as well as after the phishing documents have been sent, in order to check if they were received – a crude but effective FIN7 email delivery tracking technique.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: As FIN7 has matured, so did the quality of their phishing lures and templates, which were most often sent from fake but thoroughly disguised individuals and businesses – and occasionally from sender addresses impersonating legitimate government entities.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Their phishing has often exploited urgent, high value business matters tailored to their chosen targets.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: At individual stores, managers were contacted about lost items or sent a “receipt” claiming overcharging.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Other FIN7 phishing emails masqueraded as detailed catering orders or requests for special menus tailored to individuals with dietary restrictions.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: In early 2017, a pattern of complaints emerged and has continued for well over a year, where FIN7 has contacted stores and corporate offices to lodge food poisoning complaints with malicious attachments.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Internally dubbed “FINdigestion” by FireEye, this pattern of detailed complaints eventually expanded beyond individual complaints and into litigious concerns raised on behalf of “the government”, as shown in Figure 1.Figure 1: FDA themed spear phishing emailIt is noteworthy that the BATELEUR backdoor activity first identified by Proofpoint in July 2017, which FireEye tracks as a suspected FIN7 subgroup, uses highly-customized graphics for their targets, often created in Adobe Photoshop.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: In this same phishing campaign, FIN7’s malicious attachment was graphically themed to match, as shown in Figure 2.Figure 2: FDA themed spear phishing attachmentThroughout their operations, the professional design and continued development of phishing elements in parallel to other post-compromise tools indicated to FireEye that FIN7 was most likely a well-resourced criminal operation.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: It’s Just MetadataFireEye has tracked several FIN7 personas throughout their operations by collecting and parsing filetypes of forensic value for juicy metadata.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: In a previous blog, we shared how LNK files created by FIN7 unintentionally revealed valuable information about their development environment.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: LNK files can contain metadata that reveals attributes about the systems on which the LNKs were created, including original file paths, volume serial numbers, MAC addresses, and hostnames.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: By studying values within the LNK metadata we often identify "toolmarks," or unique values associated with distinct malware developer and operator personas.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 LNK metadata shows that the actors routinely used virtual machines with generic hostnames such as ANDY-PC or USER-PC, and default hostnames with the structure WIN-[A-Z0-9]{11} (e.g. WIN-ABCDEFGH1JK).FireEye has tracked several hostname and path toolmarks associated with FIN7’s operations, which we have used to link clusters of threat activity together.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: These toolmarks may be linked to FIN7 members who are involved in tool development or the broader criminal operation.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Notable personas from the technical data, which are explored in more detail in the Technical Appendix section, include:"andy" / "andy-pc""Hass""jimbo""Константин" (Konstantin)"oleg"This analysis allowed us to understand FIN7’s systems and correlate future attack activity to the different personas.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Furthermore, the metadata analysis helped us monitor for files generated by the group and use the established toolmarks to establish detection for other adversary methodologies (such as direct RDP or SMB access) if the group changed TTPs.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Video Playback of FIN7 OperationsWhile responding to multiple FIN7 intrusions, FireEye recovered a custom video recording capability used by FIN7 as a part of their operations.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye’s FLARE team reverse engineered the video protocol, which appeared to be custom-written by FIN7 as it has no external library dependencies, contained Cyrillic comments in the code, and required the use of a bespoke video player unique to FIN7.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: The attackers most likely leveraged this video recording capability in their arsenal to monitor operations in victim environments to inform later stages of their intrusions.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye obtained a version of the criminal developers’ video player from a trusted source and with the knowledge of the reverse engineered protocol, the FLARE team modified the source code to support multiple versions of FIN7’s custom encoding.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: With the patched source code, FireEye can decode and playback FIN7’s video monitoring for affected victims in possession of these files.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Recent Shifts in FIN7 OperationsThroughout 2018, FireEye has continued to identify multiple domains registered using patterns consistent with prior FIN7 activity, as well as campaigns using disparate TTPs that we have attributed to FIN7 with varying degrees of confidence.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: ZIP archives delivering the BIRDDOG backdoor were hosted on a portion of suspected FIN7 domains registered in 2018.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Some evidence further characterizing the nature of this campaign suggests these malicious documents were sent to financial institution customers in Eastern Europe and Central Asia as early as September 2017.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: The targeting of individuals rather than organizations would mark a significant shift in their targeting, although it is also possible that the banks spoofed in these campaigns were FIN7's ultimate targets.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Additionally, we have identified similarities between FIN7 activity and BATELEUR campaigns, which began as early as mid-2017 and have been primarily aimed at U.S.-based restaurant chains.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: These campaigns leveraged macro-embedded Word documents directly attached to the emails as well as ones hosted on Google Drive.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: The documents were meticulously crafted to appear as though they came from legitimate organizations (e.g. restaurant associations and suppliers of POS hardware).
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: This suspected FIN7 activity continued past the date of most recent arrest announced by U.S. law enforcement, although the attackers are now leveraging an updated JavaScript backdoor dubbed GRIFFON.These recent campaigns could be representative of a decisive effort to diversify TTPs to avoid detection or could indicate the formation of FIN7 splinter groups carrying out autonomous campaigns.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: As a result, organizations need to remain vigilant and continue to monitor for changes in the methods employed by the FIN7 actors.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Unveiling FIN7’s Front Company and IndustryFigure 3: Combi Security logo as retrieved from 2016 cache of combisecurity.comAccording to U.S. law enforcement, at least a portion of FIN7 activity was run out of a front company dubbed Combi Security.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: A cache of its website reveals that the company purported to be “the world leaders in the field of comprehensive protection of large information systems from modern cyber threats” with headquarters in Moscow, Haifa, and Odessa.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: We have identified job advertisements for Combi Security that have been posted on popular Russian, Ukrainian, and Uzbek job recruitment sites, as well as numerous individuals who most likely worked for the company.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Due to the seeming legitimacy of the recruitment postings, some individuals may have been unaware of illicit nature of their work.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: While the recruitment of unwitting individuals as puppets has been a common component of at least some criminal schemes – for example, reshipping mules who are recruited through postings on career sites advertising attractive work-from-home jobs – FIN7’s veiling of full-scale financial compromises as legitimate offensive security engagements is particularly notable.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: The apparent success of Combi Security in recruiting unsuspecting individuals in this manner, may lead to more of this type of technical recruitment by cyber criminals in the future.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Splitting Up?The criminal organization behind FIN7 is almost certainly comprised of many additional individuals beyond those already apprehended by law enforcement authorities.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye iSIGHT Intelligence expects that at least a portion of these malicious actors are likely to continue conducting cyber crime activity in some capacity.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Although we expect activity to continue, it is extremely common for threat actors to either modify their TTPs or temporarily halt operations following significant developments such as arrests of high-level members and/or public disclosure of TTPs that they employ.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Depending on the organizational and communication structure of the group, it is also plausible that multiple subgroups could form and carry out independent operations in the future.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Recent campaigns, as well as those using tactics that were atypical for historical FIN7 campaigns, such as the SEC campaigns with widespread targeting, may be representative of semi-autonomous groups pre-existing within, or cooperating with, the FIN7 criminal organization.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: As noted in our CARBANAK overview, certain malware families and techniques transcend strictly defined threat groups, and may be re-used by developers and operators as they transition between organizations and campaigns.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: ConclusionThese recent announcements by U.S. law enforcement highlight the positive impact that can result from synergy between private and public sector organizations in disrupting organized cyber crime operations.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: As demonstrated by FIN7, financially-motivated threat actors are becoming extremely advanced and are capable of inflicting significant harm on organizations through vast, but carefully orchestrated campaigns.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: As sophisticated threat groups continue to emerge, partnerships, such as those exhibited here, will almost certainly play a key role in combating these threats.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: AcknowledgementsJordan Nuce, Tom Bennett, Michael Bailey, and Daniel BohannonTechnical AppendixFireEye has responded to many FIN7 incidents, which has provided us extensive insight into their operations.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: As part of this blog post, we are also including numerous indicators that we attribute to FIN7 and an overview of their techniques to aid organizations in identifying malicious activity across their networks.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Phishing Documents Technical DetailsIn addition to LNK metadata, FIN7 phishing documents consistently contained artifacts detailing the local file system paths of component files used to construct the spear phishing documents.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: In the following tables, we have also included examples of the myriad of command line obfuscation techniques used by FIN7.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

text: Of particular note is the quick turnaround time between documents employing different techniques.
source: On the Hunt for FIN7_ Pursuing an Enigmatic and Evasive Global Criminal Operation _ Mandiant.html

05.13.19
Threat Report
Profile of an Adversary – FIN7

By

Bryan Austin,
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The majority of companies in either the Retail or Hospitality industries are [sadly] familiar with FIN7.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: We face many challenges in our various environments across multiple Enterprises.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Overview
This article, while focused on FIN7, is truly applicable to numerous enemies that we face.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: This article is aimed at defrocking a particular enemy and arming us all with better tools to defend against them.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: It is also worth noting that the current syndicate attributed to FIN7 is not the same organizational composition that it once was.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Thanks to high profile arrests back in 2018.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Meet the Bad Guys
FIN7 has been known to be in operation since 2012 (although some estimates put them being active as far back as 2011), when TrustWave SpiderLabs first observed threat behavior that became much more prolific after 2015.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Since then FIN7 has been identified by many organizations, including:

FireEye – FIN7
CrowdStrike – Carbon Spider
Media – Carbanak Gang/Group

This group has suspected ties to Russian organized crime and has netted roughly $1 Billion USD in the last half-decade.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Sources indicate a very loose connection with the Russian GRU.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The FIN7 group is increasingly adaptable not only to the geopolitical influences around them, but also quite capable in the environments they find themselves in.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Additionally, the group has strong ties to Ukraine, where 3 members of the FIN7 group were arrested in 2018, though often times Russian cyber operations find their first deployment in Ukraine.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Targeting
The FIN7 group began by targeting banks in the Russian Federation, but in 2015 began to transition their targeting to a broader scope to include the Middle East, Europe and the United States.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Currently, the group is known to target auto manufacturers, financial organizations, technology companies and innovators and hospitality, and retail organizations.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: As of 2018, the main targets of this group are in the financial, retail and hospitality sectors.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The US Department of Justice estimates put their intrusions at 6,500 POS terminals at 3,600 separate organizations.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: As a group, their targeting is clear, but at the onset of the attack it can seem less so.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Historically the group has targeted individuals who are listed in the organizations SEC filings which can be viewed publicly by looking the business up in the Edgar filing database.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Other individuals targeted for attack are customer service representatives who are attempting to resolve an issue they’ve identified from the attack.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Techniques
FIN7 begins the attack via malware delivery.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: This starts as a spear phishing email sent to the initial target.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Generally the sentiment of the email is anger and accusations against the target’s organization either due to a policy or a product.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: In short, the attacker is disguised as a highly dissatisfied customer.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The attacker performs a technique commonly called “amygdala hijacking” by eliciting a fear response in the target, and proceeds to reinforce the hijack by making threats and demands of the target which puts the individual on a defensive stance.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Once the target responds, the actor then shifts to a deescalation tactics which eases the tension of the situation and causes the target to let their guard down in order to develop a more civil rapport with the target.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Additionally, the actor then begins to offer help to assist the target in resolving the issue which they themselves have created, thus “hooking” the target by making themselves seem to be the hero.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The actor then begins to use the first name of the target to establish a sense of intimacy, common knowledge and familiarity.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The exchange then leads to an initial document delivery that is usually benign but possesses a tracking pixel that allows the actor to verify whether or not the target is opening attachments, and if so can provide initial visibility into the system of the target.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The documents for this phase are often either blank or built for the campaign and correspond to the topic of conversation from the attacker.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The second document the attacker sends is usually the one with the actual payload.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: This document has either a VBA macro or an embedded OLE which persuades the target to run these in order to drop the first stage loaders.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: If the first stage loader is not dropped, the attacker resumes the threat tactic and escalates the issue to the target’s supervisor which indicates an extensive amount of OSINT and revealing the extent the attacker is willing to pursue a single individual.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Tools
Since FIN7 focuses on obtaining financial data, they rely heavily on malware to scrape consumer credit card information from Point Of Sale (POS) systems as well as other account information from databases in the network.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The data stolen is then used to steal funds from victims and commit fraud, which is how the organization funds itself.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: There is also a possible connection to the 2016 SWIFT attacks, many of which have since been attributed to North Korea, however evidence of this is limited and open to interpretation.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The group typically follows a standard sequence of events: Spear phishing a target with a document loaded with a malware payload which as of May 2018 has been the Griffon payload, or a combination of SQLRat and DNSBot historically.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: These trends, observed by FireEye/Mandiant and Flashpoint respectively, always lead to the loading of an additional payload which is most commonly the Tinymet meterpreter payload to establish a beachhead in the network.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: This begins the beaconing back to the Cobalt Strike servers.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: To establish persistence, the group then injects a scheduled task to reestablish the C2 connection to Cobalt Strike which historically is run twice a day.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: From there the adversary loads process injection tools or memory scrapers (commonly mimikatz) and pivots using tools like powersploit, RDP services, and PowerAdmin Exec.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: A new development was the discovery of the Astra PHP Panel being used in conjunction with SQLRat.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: This discovery was posted in March 2019 from Flashpoint, was tracked back via the tie in established by the US DOJ; the Combi Security company was acting as a front and recruitment platform for the FIN7 group.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The malware most commonly associated with FIN7 is the Carbanak family, which the group gained as its common moniker.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The Carbanak malware is not, however, exclusive to FIN7, nor do they use it explicitly.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Currently, the group is using macro enabled word documents and spear phishing to deliver initial payloads that pull down second stage loaders like Spy.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Sekur, although recently the Bateleur JavaScript backdoor has come into fashion as of November 2017.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Additionally, the group heavily targets the following CVEs:

CVE-2015-2545
CVE-2015-1701
CVE-2017-0199

The group has begun branching out in using various malware versions and a full listing of the known IOCs for the new SQLRat and DNSBot additionally the Astra PHP panel are included at the end of this document as well as a list of links to the open source projects to allow for greater research.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Defensive Options
This adversary is persistent, capable, adaptable, and competent.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: That being said, there are a variety of options to begin defending your environment.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The most critical aspect is detection.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Due to FIN7’s heavy use of spear phishing to deliver malicious MSFT Office documents to users, the most common exploits are scripts written in PowerShell or VBA and executed as macros in the documents.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Blocking macro execution and enabling verbose logging from PowerShell (although storage space is expensive) is an excellent start to defend against this group and others who favor sophisticated phishing attacks.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Additionally, the usage of honey tokens in the environment can give a high-fidelity alert regarding access.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: In the case of FIN7, string searches can detect user credentials to a database or a fake credit card number.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Tracking known indicators based on the actor’s activity and setting alarms once IOCs are detected are also effective defense options.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Many organizations are able to track the activity in their environment, but taking a more proactive stance is optimal.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: First and foremost it is imperative to know where critical data lies.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: In this case, PCI/DSS scoping can act as an initial point of reference, but knowing where card data and financial data live can create a position of strength for defenders.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Vulnerability management is also a critical piece to the holistic cyber defense.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Though FIN7 does not actively exploit vulnerabilities at the time of this writing (e.g. CVE’s 2545, 1701, & 0199), they can potentially begin to do so in the future.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Vulnerability Management allows you to take an in depth stock of your IT assets.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: TTPs posted by intelligence and research groups can help prioritize patches based on exploits available for the vulnerability.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: However, it is important to note that many adversaries gain access to an organization not via high and critical vulnerabilities, but by chaining together a number of vulnerabilities considered to have low and medium severity.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Monitoring your systems for scheduled task changes is also critical.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Be on the lookout for new scheduled tasks, especially those that use a .js file extension.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
If possible establish a host based detection for new files in the %appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\ directory, particularly any with a .dot extension as well as new files in %appdata%\local\Storage\.
Ensuring that your toolsets and configurations are set up properly can not only deter threats, but also cause problems for adversaries.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Properly configured EDR, script blocking can prevent things like JavaScript or macros to deploy while OS hardening guidelines modeled after groups like NIST and CIS will also cause more issues for attackers than most tools.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Finally, user education is a key component in every organization.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Phishing is a highly used method for an initial foothold in organizations.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: According to Mimecast, 97% of breaches start with phishing.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Until perfect phishing protection is created, users need to know how to recognize a malicious email, how to respond and what the company policies are for mitigating the risk.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Good reporting can prevent a major campaign from being effective and can potentially cause a large portion of attacker infrastructure to be burned if reported correctly and responded to properly.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Recap of Minimum Baseline Defenses
Below is a recap of what should be considered minimum Enterprise defense and/or planning goals to reach first.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: The higher the number below the greater the impact to defense, however there is typically a corresponding increase to the deployment lifecycle complexity.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html
Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Patch Relevant CVEs

CVE-2015-2545
CVE-2015-1701
CVE-2017-0199

2.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Log & Monitor on Enterprise Host Environment

Task Scheduler jobs
New Task Scheduler jobs
%appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\
%appdata%\local\Storage\

3.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Alert (& Groom) on the Monitored Enterprise Host Environment

Task Scheduler jobs with .js extension
New Task Scheduler jobs with .js extension
%appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\*.dot
%appdata%\local\Storage\*.dot

4.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Blocking macro execution in application userland with GPO
5.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
EDR JS and macro script blocking

Conclusion
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: In conclusion, FIN7 is an adversary worthy of concern with compromises resulting in the loss of up to a billion dollars.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: While this adversary is dangerous, basic security hygiene as outlined by both the NIST and CIS frameworks can reduce the actor’s effectiveness in your environment as well as reduce the mean time to detection and mitigation.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: Additionally, knowledge of the group’s tools, tactics, and processes allow defenders to more effectively predict the actions of the attacker, all of which can reduce your costs and the threats to your organization.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text: This tipper, as of late April 2019, contains new TTPs and IOCs that are worth a review by members.
source: Profile of an Adversary - FIN7 _ Deepwatch.html

text:
Here is the summary of those:

Mapping the specific new malware signatures
Mapping the specific new domains
Astra IOC in particular
Two years ago, FIN7 uploaded their Carbanak Malware to VirusTotal containing over 100k Lines of Code (LoC)
